loans.name: Annastasia

texts.en:
Annastasia is a dairy farmer in Kangundo town. She supplies milk to various milk retailers in the area, and she has been in this business for eight years. She is 49 years old and married to Patrick, who also supports the family. They have four children.

This is her first loan term with KADET LTD., and she plans to use the amount to buy a dairy cow. This will enable her to get more milk for selling and thereby, make more income, with which she will pay school fees for her children.

She hopes to buy more dairy cattle, be successful in dairy farming and make more income so as to provide a good education for her children.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Ammer Group

texts.en: This group is called Ammer and consists of six men who live in Sana'a, Yemen. They have requested a loan of 300,000 YER from AMB. Among the borrowers is Fares, age 22, who is a hard-working man. He lives with his relatives in a poor area of Sana`a. Although his income is not very consistent, he does what he can to provide for the family. He has requested a youth loan of 50,000 YER from AMB in order to buy a washing machine and fridge for his home.

loans.use: to buy a washing machine and fridge for his home.

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud is a 30-year-old single man. He lives with his parents and five siblings. He cooperates financially with his family members to pay for their heavy life expenses. Mahmoud has been working in the agricultural field since 2012. His job consists of organizing the land and cleaning it out to prepare it for planting and raising crops. Today, he is asking to borrow a youth loan from Kiva's partner, Vitas s.a.l, to improve his business operations by purchasing agricultural tools and additional plants. Mahmoud is very optimistic about his business prospects, and he is willing to request additional Kiva loans to be able to further expand his work.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural tools and additional plants.

loans.name: Vagif

texts.en:
Vagif is 57 years old. He is married and the father of two children. Vagif and his family live and work in the rural village. His wife and daughter work at home, taking care of animals and producing the milk products. His son helps him in selling meat, yogurt, milk and poultry. 

Vagif himself is a farmer. He has 17 years of experience in this area. He earns his living in farming by persistent work. He would like to expand his business, since his children are grown, and he needs to marry them and provide them with housing. He plans to start a fruit and vegetable selling business, in particular. Now, he is requesting a loan to buy sheep, a cow with its calf and poultry. He plans to use the income for the marriage of his son.

loans.use: to buy sheep, a cow with its calf and poultry.

loans.name: Nune

texts.en:
Nune is 40 years old, and she lives in the village Sevaqar with her husband and three sons. Nune has graduated from Kapan Medical College, and she has learned the skills of a nurse, but she has never worked in the field. It has been nearly 20 years that she and her husband have been engaged in farming and agriculture. They own a very nice, cute house and a plot of land, where they cultivate tomatoes, beans, cucumbers and greens. They have an animal barn, where they keep two pigs and five piglets. They also have 60 beehives. 

All around their farm, they work together with love and joy. They have a lot to do, but they say that together, they overcome any hard work so any achievement comes to be a kind of reward for their efforts and hard work. 

Nune and her husband want to enlarge their farm with cattle, so they asked for a loan of 1,100,000 Armenian drams for the purchase of two bulls, wax papers and frames for their beehives and also some animal fodder for the winter months.

loans.use: To buy two bulls, wax papers and frames for the beehives and also some fodder for the animals.

loans.name: Gezim

texts.en:
With the help of his previous Kiva loan, Gezim bought raw materials for making handcrafted baskets. He is very grateful to all of you for your kindness! 

He paid off the previous loan and is applying for another loan for the same purpose. 

He is extremely grateful for the financial support he receives from his lenders.

loans.use: buy raw materials to make handcrafted baskets

loans.name: Jean Baptiste

texts.en: Jean Baptiste is 59 years old. He sells beans and rice and has been doing so for a period of three years to date.  He is married with three children who all go to school. With the loan, he would like to buy more beans to sell. The profits from the business will be used for paying school fees for his children.

loans.use: To buy more beans to sell.

loans.name: Enatha

texts.en: Enatha is 44 years old. She has sold rice, sugar and salt for the past eight months. With this loan, she would like to buy more rice and sugar for sale. The profits from the business will be used to pay school her children's school fees.

loans.use: to buy more rice and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence, age 21, sells soaps, cooking oil, and rice to earn a living. She has been engaged in her business for the last two years. 

With her loan funds, she would like to buy more items such as soaps and cooking oil to offer for sale. 

The profits from the business will be used to provide food for the family.

loans.use: to buy more soaps and cooking oil to offer for sale

loans.name: Hanife

texts.en:
With the loan that Hanife got last August thanks to all of you Kiva lenders, she bought feed for her livestock. She is requesting another loan this time as well for the same reason. She hopes that she will get the same response from all of you. 

With joy in her heart, she thanks you again for all of your financial help.

loans.use: to buy feed for her livestock.

loans.name: Liliane

texts.en: Liliane is married with three children. Her husband is a truck driver. She has requested the loan for buying more items such as juices, eggs and breads for sale. The profits expected from the business will be used to reinvest in the similar business.

loans.use: to buy more juices, eggs and bread for sale.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria of Hasaan, Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental, is a 68-year-old married woman with six children. To make a living, she owns and manages a farm of banana and coconut. In three years, she earned 3,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) a month from selling harvested bananas and copra in the market. 

She became a member of GDMPC in the year 2010 and gained access to microfinance services. She is now requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP to finance the costs of weeding maintenance and buy manure fertilizer. She plans to acquire another piece of land for coconut to have another source of income for the entire family.

loans.use: to finance the costs of weeding maintenance and buy manure fertilizer.

loans.name: Aleksandre

texts.en:
Aleksandre is 26 years old. He lives in Senaki District with his sister and parents. His sister works at local pharmacy and gets a small monthly income which is the only source of income for their family. It is hardly enough for food and, according to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. Aleksandre has requested loans from local financial institutions several times to start-up a  family business without any success. His loan requests are rejected all the time because of his low income and his family’s poor living conditions.

Aleksandre is requesting a loan from Credo to start-up family business. He will use his loan to start a used-clothing business and he plans to rent a commercial space to open his shop. Aleksandre's loan has been approved within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo that envisages the provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the rural poor who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. Aleksandre's new business, financed with his Kiva start-up loan, will significantly increase his family's income. As his new business is started, Aleksandre hopes to significantly improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to start a used-clothing business

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 52-year-old married man from Lebanon who is living with his wife and three children, who are still attending school. He has owned a butchery since 1998 with two full-time employees helping him with the work. 

Today, he is applying for a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to renovate his shop and improve his operations. We all know that buying meat from unknown and unclean places can cause diseases. So, Ahmad’s only target is to sanitize his environment and make renovations in order to attract customers as much as possible to buy his fresh and clean meat kept in good and healthy conditions. In the future, Ahmad plans to expand his business into other areas.

loans.use: to renovate his shop and improve his operations.

loans.name: Aldo

texts.es:
Aldo es un joven de la ciudad de Concepción, con gran visión de crecer y poder independizarse, trabaja en dependencia de alguien y cuenta que le gustaría algún día poder tener su propia farmacia.
Está estudiando la carrera de Farmacia, la cual quiere poder ejercer el día de mañana. Su meta es día a día seguir capacitándose y seguir creciendo, ya que sabe que la única forma de salir adelante es estudiar.
Solicita de este crédito para poder invertirlo en pagar las cuotas de su facultad, ya que así podrá aligerarse y seguir estudiando.
texts.en: Aldo is a young man from the city of Concepción who has a great vision of growing and becoming independent. He works, dependent on another person, and he mentions that he would like to have his own pharmacy one day. Aldo is studying Pharmacy in the university, which he wants to put into practice tomorrow. His goal is to continue his training and growing each day. Aldo knows that the only way to get ahead is through education. He is requesting this loan in order to invest it in his school payments. Then he will be able to relieve himself from this worry and keep studying.

loans.use: to pay school fees.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy hair gels, relaxers, and artificial hair for her salon

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard lives in the Litein area of Kenya. He has two children and has been doing this work for five years. His primary income sources are milk, crops and a personal business.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "Farming!" His biggest challenge is lack of funds. An animal on the farm has been given the name of Cheseger.

Benard was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: "Because they offer grace period in the first loan." This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: "That they uplift the living standard of small-scale farmers."

His highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked how this loan will benefit his family, Benard replied, "In paying school fees for his children."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Benard owns the following: cow, poultry and motorcycle, but does not own a pig, pump, bicycle or automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net, but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV or DVD.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase poultry.

loans.name: Hurelhuu

texts.en:
Mr. Hurelhuu is 24 years old. He lives with his wife and a child in a Ger (Mongolian housing tent) in the Uvs province of Mongolia. His wife is a senior student of a local university and takes care of their child. 

He has been running a taxi service in town since 2008. He has gained lot of experience and regular clients over the years. He has recently replaced his car with a better second-hand car, but it still needs some repairs and replacement spare parts are needed to operate his business smoothly with no pause. 

He is now requesting loan of 1,000,000 MNT (Mongolian tugriks) to purchase spare parts and cover the repairing cost of his car to smoothly provide taxi service in town. He is a hardworking, enthusiastic and energetic young man.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and cover cost of repairing his car to smoothly provide taxi service in town.

loans.name: Elnur

texts.en:
Elnur is 26 years old, a young client who is not married yet. He sells food products and has 2 years’ experience in this field. He is very kind, caring, and energetic in his work. His father has died and he is living with his mother. Elnur doesn’t have a higher education, so he chose this occupation. 

In order to marry and have his own separate house, Elnur has asked for a 1500 AZN loan in order to buy a refrigerator and install shelves in the grocery store. He hopes that this loan will help him to increase the goods displayed and thus improve his income. This will be his second loan.

loans.use: to buy a refrigerator for his store

loans.name: Rouguiatou's Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sobouldé a été créé le 17 Mai 2011 lors de l’inauguration leur banc villageois. Ce  groupe en sein des femmes très braves et désireuses d’apporter un plus à leur foyer. Elles habitent toutes le même village. Il existe une parfaite solidarité entre les femmes. Elles font comme activité principale le  petit commerce et la fabrication de savon traditionnel.

Madame Rouguiatou (assise à l’extrême gauche), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe, elle est mariée et mère de cinq enfants dont 01 fille. Son activité consiste à acheter de l’huile de palme, du riz et autres produits alimentaires en gros au marché central de la commune pour la revente en détail au village.

Avec son nouveau crédit, elle compte acheter 03 bidons d’huile de palme de 20 litres à 18 000 F CFA le bidon et 05 sacs de riz à 13 500 F CFA le sac.

Les bénéfices lui permettront en plus de renforcer son épargne, d’apporter son soutien à son mari dans la gestion des besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
The Sobouldé group was created on the 17th of May 2011 on the occasion of the official inauguration of their village bank. This is a group of good and honest women who wish to improve life for their household. They all live in the same village and there is true solidarity between them. They work in the production and commerce of traditional soap.

Mrs. Rouguiatou (who is sitting on the far right), is the star borrower of the group, and is married with five children of which one girl. Her work consists of buying palm oil, rice and other food products wholesale at the central market for retail sale in the village.

With her new loan, she plans to buy three cans of 20 liters of palm oil  at 18 000 F CFA per can and five bags of rice at 13 500 F CFA per bag.

The profits will enable her to increase her savings, and to help her husband to manage the family needs.

loans.use: to buy 3 cans of 20 liters of palm oil at 18 000 F CFA a can and 5 bags of rice at 13 500 F CFA a bag.

loans.name: Truphena

texts.en:
Truphena lives in the Eldoret area of Kenya and has one child. This area is a primary milk-producing region. For the past two years, Truphena has been a farmer who sells milk, eggs, and crops. Truphena states that "milking and feeding cows!" are the most enjoyable parts of farming. Her biggest challenge is the "expansion of dairy plant." One of her animals is named Chemurgutstubborn. When asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for her loan Truphena replied, "it assists small-scale farmers with finances to improve production." She learned about a savings culture during her required Juhudi microfinance training session. Truphena's greatest monthly expenses are farming costs. She believes that her loan will benefit her family by "increased income and thus more disposable income."

Truphena is requesting a loan to buy a dairy cow. As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Truphena owns a cow, poultry, a pump, a bicycle, and a motorcycle but does not own a pig or an automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on individual loans. Truphena has a household  mosquito net and DVD but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, a sewing machine, or TV.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: to purchase dairy cow

loans.name: Diane

texts.en: Diane is 35 years old.  She sells local-made beers. She is married with three children. With the loan, she would like to buy more sorghum to make local beers for sale. The profits from the business will be used to generate more savings.

loans.use: to buy more sorghum to make local beers for sale.

loans.name: Mario Efigenio

texts.es:
Mario, solicita un nuevo préstamo porque este es un recurso muy importante para invertir  y generar ganancias, ya sea económicamente o con el rendimiento de cosechas; este le permitirá comprar insumos agrícolas para una manzana de maíz sembrada, entre estos están: 3 sacos de abono, insecticidas, asimismo para pagar alquiler del terreno y  concentrado para el ganado.
El crédito anterior  fue favorable, ya que logro obtener una cosecha abundante y libre de plagas; en cuanto al ganado se mantiene y no fue necesario venderlo a pesar del alto costo del mantenimiento. Cuenta que gracias al crédito obtuvo mejores resultados económicos y de ello mismo ha facilitado para la familia, también aumento un miembro más en la familia.
texts.en:
Mario is requesting another loan because this is an important resource to invest in to earn income, whether it be economically or with his harvest's performance. This will allow him to buy agricultural supplies for planting corn and other items such as 3 sacks of fertilizer, and insecticide. He will also be able to pay rent on the land and buy cattle feed.

His last loan was very successful because it allowed him to have an abundant harvest free of infestations. As for the cattle he raises, he didn't have to sell despite the high cost of raising them. He says that thanks to the loan, he got better financial results and that has made things easier for his family. They also added another member to their family.

loans.use: to buy 3 sacks of fertilizer, insecticide, and to pay rent on the land and cattle feed

loans.name: Naume

texts.en:
Naume is 47 years old and is married with six children.  Out the six children, four attend school.  Naume and her husband are farmers growing mainly matooke (bananas), sugarcane and maize on a smaller scale for both home and commercial purposes. Currently Naume's husband is sick and she is in charge of looking after the family including paying school fees.  

Naume has now approached Ugafode for a loan of UGX 1,500,000 so that she can pay school fees for their daughter who is in a nursing school, and the other children in primary school.  Naume is unable to raise this money at once but can afford paying back in smaller installments.  Her dream is to have her daughter complete her studies and maybe in the future she can support the family.

Naume is a hardworking person who is only constrained by the weather conditions affecting agriculture, as well as the price fluctuation for agricultural products on the market.

loans.use: To pay tuition

loans.name: Nemer

texts.en: Nemer is a 56-year-old married Lebanese man living with his wife and six children. His work is the family's main source of income. Nemer has 23 years of experience working in the agricultural field. He owns a plot of land where he cultivates different types of fruits and vegetables, which he sells to multiple grocery stores and traders. With his requested loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l, he will install a water station which will help him to irrigate his crops. The water station will allow him to improve his product development, and thus increase his sales and income. Nemer is very confident that the loan will help him to meet his business needs.

loans.use: to install a water station to irrigate his crops.

loans.name: Feryal

texts.en:
Feryal is a 45-year-old married Lebanese woman living with her husband and five children who are still attending school. Her husband, who works in the construction field, is the main income source of the family. As for her, she has owned a bakery since 2011 where she produces pastries and has more than 10 years of experience in the same occupation.

Today, Feryal needs to get a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to purchase baking machinery. She states that this machine will help her increase her business productivity which will return higher profits. Feryal hopes that her business grows and dreams to be able to provide her children a good future and the best education throughout all her hard work.

loans.use: to purchase a baking machinery

loans.name: Husein

texts.en:
Husein is a 21-year-old single man who has been selling perfumes for three years. In 2011, he started his own business to improve his living.

Husein has a very good reputation and is talented in his domain. He is applying for a youth loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua in order to increase his selection of merchandise with special-release fragrances.

His work is mobile, so he passes among villages to sell his products. He prefers to expand his business working area and keep it mobile to make sure that his customers are well-served and satisfied.

loans.use: To increase his inventory with special-release fragrances

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is married and lives in rural Lyantonde. He collects milk from farmers in villages and brings it to the town center by truck to sell to a dairy which later transports it to the city. He is pictured here on a truck with milk cans.

John is requesting a loan to buy milk. Most of the farmers he buys from usually want cash and yet the diary pays only at the end of each month. John is optimistic that his loan will increase his sales and monthly profit. He thanks Ugafode for meeting his need when no one else was willing.

loans.use: to buy milk

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is a mason in Tala town. He construct houses and has been in this business for 12 years. He is 42 years old, married and has three children. 

This is his first loan term with KADET LTD., and he plans to use the amount to buy construction materials and equipment for use. These include wheelbarrows, shovels and plumb-lines. He will use the generated income to pay school fees for his children.

He hopes to be successful in his masonry business and be able to provide for his family.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for his home-building business.

loans.name: Shaista

texts.en:
Shaista is a 49-year-old woman; she has been stitching clothes for the past four years. She stitches for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. 

However, due to lack of availability of funds, she is unable to meet with the daily demand of her customers. For this reason, she requested a loan of 25,000 PKR (Pakistan rupees) from Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan amount to buy more spools of threads in different colors with packs of laces, zippers and buttons to create a means of increasing revenues so she may able to generate a healthier source of income. She is in her second loan cycle and is thankful to Kashf for its tremendous support.

loans.use: to buy more spools of threads in different colors with packs of laces, zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Moustafa

texts.en:
Moustafa, age 30, crafts specially-made carpets to earn an income. He has eight years of experience in this domain. He started his own business in 2011 and is dedicated to developing his enterprise in order to meet his family's needs. He is a Palestinian refugee born in Lebanon. He and his wife have three children.

Moustafa has developed a strong reputation and has devoted his efforts to managing and expanding his business. He is applying for a youth loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua and intends to use his loan funds to increase his business merchandise with specially-made carpets for the winter season. He will also buy necessary tools and materials used in the knitting process.

Moustafa is a hard worker who puts a great deal of effort into developing his business, responding to customer demand, and improving his family's socioeconomic situation.

loans.use: to increase his business merchandise with specially-made carpets for the winter season, as well as buying necessary tools and materials used in the knitting process.

loans.name: Safiyya

texts.en:
Safiyya is 24 years old, a young client who lives with her parents in her hometown. Safiyya sells fruits and vegetables. She has been doing this work for 5 years, and she has been doing it by herself ever since she started. She really enjoys her work because she feels free and independent. At the same time, it’s going very well for her, and this helps her to feel calmer. Safiyya's mother also helps her with the business because it is the family's only source of income.

Safiyya is a very kind girl, and her hopes for the future include expanding her business, getting married, and caring for her parents. But now her primary goal is to expand her business by buying new fruit trees, fertilizers, and seeds. For this, she is requesting a loan of 1900 AZN. She hopes that this loan will help her to increase the goods she offers and thus improve her income. This will be her fourth loan.

loans.use: to buy new fruit trees and fertilizers

loans.name: Husein

texts.en:
Husein is a 21-year-old single man who has been making furniture since eight years ago in order to support his six other family members, for whom he is responsible. 

He was only 13 years old when he quit his intermediate class and started working for his own and his family's living. Husein has a very good reputation and special talent in his specialty, painting furniture.

Today, he is applying for a youth loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua to buy new tools for his business. These tools will help him to develop his business and finish requested work in a short period of time and with excellent quality.

He hopes to keep on developing his work and expanding his business to keep his family members and customers satisfied.

loans.use: to buy new tools for his business.

loans.name: Zipporah

texts.en:
Zipporah has a retail shop in Kangundo town and has been in the business for three years. She is 35 years old and married with three children.

This is Zipporah's second loan term with KADET LTD., and she plans to use the amount to buy more stock of goods for selling. These include sugar, flour, cooking oil and detergents. She will use the generated income to pay school fees for her children. 

She hopes to grow her retail business and become a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: To buy sugar, flour and cooking oil for selling.

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey, 29, is married to Rachael and has 1 child. He sells charcoal in Kitengela town. He has been in this business for the past 4 years. 

This will be his first loan, and he plans to buy charcoal to sell. He will use the income generated to pay school fees for his child. He hopes to grow his business and open a salon for his wife.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal for sell.

loans.name: Avancemos Seguros  (Portoviejo) Group

texts.es:
En la parroquia San Pablo de la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúnen cada quince días las 9 socias y los 2 socios   del Banco Comunal Avancemos Seguros. Los mismos que se dedican a diversas actividades tales como comercio en general, servicios, entre otras cosas. Los integrantes de este banco comunal son personas muy humildes pero trabajadoras que con su esfuerzo esperan sacar adelante a sus familias.

Una de las socias de este grupo es la señora Mónica, tiene 20 años  de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre  de la cual tiene una niña de 2 años. Su marido es artesano. Ella estudia Auditoria en una Universidad de la ciudad. 

Doña Mónica con la intención de ganar algo por su cuenta y con esto poder salir adelante se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y también vende en la universidad donde ella estudia. Trabaja todos los días y a cualquier hora ya que no tiene un horario fijo sino cuando ella puede, deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Su mercadería  la va a comprar a Guayaquil o a Manta cada quince días o al mes de acuerdo a lo que necesite. Tiene más de 3  años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: pantalones, blusas, camisetas y ropa de niños. Está en el Banco Comunal desde el inicio y le gusta porque el grupo es unido y confiable.

Su sueño es  terminar su carrera universitaria para conseguir un buen trabajo.
texts.en:
In the parish of San Pablo in the city of Portoviejo, the 11 members (nine females and two males) of the communal bank group Avancemos Seguros (we advance surely) get together every other week. These members run various businesses in sales, services, and other things. The members of this group are very humble but hardworking people who are fighting to help their families get ahead. 

One of the group members is Monica. She is 20 years old and in a civil marriage, from which she has a 2-year-old daughter. Her husband is an artisan. Monica studying auditing in a university in the city. Monica also sells clothing door-to-door in order to earn money and get ahead. She even sells clothing in the university where she studies. Monica works every day without a set schedule, but whenever she has time. She allows her customers to buy items on credit and she collects payments every two weeks. Monica buys her merchandise in Guayaquil or Manta every two weeks or month, depending on when she needs it. She has been working in this business for three years and it has gone very well for her.

Monica will use this loan to buy more merchandise such as pants, blouses, t-shirts, and children's clothing. She has been a member of this communal bank group since its beginning and she likes it because it is united and trustworthy. Monica's dream is to finish her university studies and find a good job.

loans.use: to buy pants, blouses, t-shirts, and children's clothing.

loans.name: Jonis

texts.es: Jonis de 57 años de edad se dedica ala venta de refrescos, bebidas frías, pasabocas y bollos, o amasijos de maíz envueltos en hojas de la misma planta. Jonis habita con su familia a orillas del mar, donde el calor y el turismo potencializan la venta de refrescos en estas cálidas tierras, negocio que inició desde hace 4 años, cuando, los vecinos del sector le sugirieron que vendiera cervezas y gaseosas; él empezó con una caja de cada producto y paulatinamente ha incrementado su venta, porque venden hasta 10 cajas semanales de cervezas y gaseosas a vecinos y transeúntes del sector, desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche. Su meta mas adelante es vender todo tipo de víveres y terminar de remodelar su vivienda, además de fidelizar su clientela y aumentar el volumen de sus ventas. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace ala Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará cervezas, gaseosas y pasabocas, las cuales compra directamente al camión y esto hace que se evite el costo de los intermediarios. De esta manera su credikiva resultará ser exitoso.
texts.en:
Jonis, 57 years old, works by selling drinks, cold drinks, snacks and "bollos" (dough from corn put inside corn leaves). Jonis lives with his family on the seashore, where the heat and tourism enable the sale of drinks in this hot area. He has had this business for four years, when his neighbors suggested that he sell beer and drinks. He started with one case of each product and slowly increased his sales. He sells up to 10 cases of beer and drinks per week to his neighbors and passersby. He works from 8am until 8pm.

His goal is to sell all kinds of supplies and finish remodeling his home, in addition to building customer loyalty and increasing the volume of his sales. He is currently applying for a Kiva loan, which is the first time he is financing through Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo. With the loan, he will buy beer, drinks, and snacks. He will buy directly from the truck, which eliminates indirect selling costs. This will make his Kiva credit a success.

loans.use: to buy beer, soft drinks, and snacks

loans.name: Bushra

texts.en:
Bushra is a 30-year-old married woman who has been doing a business of shoe making for many years. She also manufactures buckles, which are used in the embellishment of shoes. She beautifully makes buckles and prepares shoes at home and then sells them in the local market. By this time, she has attained a regular list of customers and makes enough to contribute to the family income.

Her husband works as a laborer and earns insufficient income to support his family alone. She is a mother of four children and is motivated to provide for her family. 

To cope with the increasing demand of her customers, she requested a loan of 20,000 PKR (Pakistan rupees) to purchase raw material including leather, plastic soles, threads, sequins and pearls in various colors to increase her production. She is in her second loan cycle and has shown excellent repayment behavior. She wishes to utilize part of revenues to provide better living standards to her family.

loans.use: to purchase raw material including leather, plastic soles, threads, sequins and pearls in various colors.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is a 45-year-old businesswoman from Liberia. She is married and has three children between the ages of 25 and 7; two are currently attending school, and they all live at home. She completed grade 4 before starting her business.  

She describes herself as a hardworking woman. She lives and works in Paynesville North, which has the largest market in Montserrado County. The area is home to “round-time marketers,” the local term for traders who travel to the interior regions of the country to purchase goods to sell throughout the county. Because of this, there is a large number of wholesalers operating in the area who distribute to the markets in the county, including supplying the capital city of Monrovia. 

Rebecca has a shop business which has sold soap, milk, sugar, rice, candy, etc., for the past 10 years. She works 15 hours each day at her business.  Her greatest challenge in business is payment of rent for the shop. 

She intends to use the loan to buy more soap, milk, sugar, rice, candy, etc. She started her business by her husband. She likes her business because she makes a profit. She hopes to one day build her own shop.  

She wants to thank the Kiva lenders in advance for their help.

loans.use: to buy more soap, milk, sugar, rice, candy, etc.

loans.name: Nazia

texts.en: Nazia, 25, is a married woman and mother of one child. She accepted the fact that if her husband works alone, they will not be able to meet the expenses of their household. Together with her husband, she manages the household while operating her own tailoring business. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her family's everyday expenses. She requested a loan of 15,000 PKR to buy threads of different colors, buttons, needles and packs of zippers to meet the increasing demand of her customers without fail.

loans.use: to buy threads of different colors, buttons, needles, and packs of zippers

loans.name: Natalia

texts.en:
Natalia is 39 years old. She lives in the small village of Sagarejo District with husband Teimuraz. Natalia has requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for family business start-up, but has never had any success. Her loan request was rejected each time because of her family's low income and poor living conditions. 

Natalia is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, she has a milk cow and produces cheese products to sell. Teimuraz has a car and works among the local people as a taxi driver. Natalia requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Natalia has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages providing business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people who do not have access to traditional credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With her loan, Natalia will purchase a stock of groceries and open a local grocery shop. Opening a shop will increase the income of the family. Part of the income will be reinvested in the same business. This new business initiative financed with this Kiva start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to open a grocery shop.

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en:
Nasreen is a 49-year-old married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store with her husband at the corner of her house. Her husband also assists her by purchasing stocks of goods from the market and dealing with customers by staffing the shop. Over time, they have become popular in their community for providing good quality products, and they make enough to meet the expenses of their six children. 

Nasreen has requested a loan of PKR 20,000 to buy packs of salt, biscuits, and beverages to meet with the increasing demand at her store. She is expecting boost in her earnings and dreams of expanding her business in the future. She wishes to utilize part of her revenues to deal with personal expenses and to increase her business capital.

loans.use: to buy packs of salt, biscuits, and beverages.

loans.name: Shabana

texts.en:
Shabana is a vigorous 30-year-old lady. She has been stitching clothes for ten years. She stitches for the people of her community and uses the income to help support her entire family. She has retained many regular customers and makes a good amount of income to contribute to the family's income. However, due to a lack of funds, she is unable to meet with the daily demands of her customers. 

For this reason, Shabana has requested a loan of PKR 25,000 from Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan to buy more spools of threads in different colors along with packs of laces, zippers, and buttons. She is confident that these purchases will allow her to increase her revenues so she can generate a healthier income. This will be her third loan, and she is thankful to Kashf for its tremendous support.

loans.use: to buy thread, laces, zippers, and buttons.

loans.name: Khursheed

texts.en: Khursheed is a married lady and a loving mother of five children. She runs a milk business. She has two buffaloes and sells their milk to many of her neighbors along with the butter and cheese that she makes from the milk. She looks after the buffaloes and performs the task of collecting milk from them while her husband sells the milk to different places on a daily basis. She needs to increase her sales to earn more profit. For this reason, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of 20,000 PKR to buy another buffalo to milk which will allow her to cater to more customers. She wishes to spend part of her revenue on everyday expenditures for her children including food, clothing, and education.

loans.use: to buy another buffalo to milk

loans.name: Balqees

texts.en:
Balqees is a 44-year-old married woman who enjoys doing the work of hand embroidery. She started doing work with her daughters. Her embroidery patterns are very popular in her territory. Her husband is a driver and earns insufficient income to support her family. She is motivated to provide her family with the basic necessities of life, including food, clothes and education. 

In order to meet the growing demand for her embroidery, she requested a loan of 35,000 PKR (Pakistan rupees) from Kashf Foundation. In this way, she will be able to purchase more packs of sequins, needles and threads in different colors to complete the orders of her customers on time. She is in her third loan cycle and hopes to have a good experience with this loan.

loans.use: to purchase more packs of sequins, needles and threads in different colors.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a 41-year-old businesswoman from Liberia. She is married and has five children between the ages of 26 and 16; one is currently attending school and two live at home. She completed grade 3 before starting her business. She describes herself as a hardworking woman.

She lives and works in Paynesville North, which has the largest market in Montserrado County. The area is home to “round-time marketers,” the local term for traders who travel to the interior regions of the country to purchase goods to sell throughout the county. Because of this, there are a large number of wholesalers operating in the area who distribute to the markets in the county, including supplying the capital city of Monrovia. 

Beatrice has a shop business which has sold soft drinks, beer, Guinness, etc., for the past 13 years. She works 18 hours each day at her business. Her greatest challenge in business is having few goods in her shop. She intends to use the loan to buy more soft drinks, beer, Guinness, etc. She started her business by her husband. She likes her business because she makes a profit. She hopes to one day to open another shop.  

She wants to thank the Kiva lenders in advance for their help.

loans.use: to buy more soft drinks, beer, Guinness, etc.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is 51 years old, and she is single with three grown-up children. She lives in her own home. For the past eight years, she has been working at her business selling soft drinks. She does her selling in front of her house.

Naomi gets her supply from the depot and sells at home to her customers and neighbors throughout the week. 

Naomi is a hardworking woman who wants to get her grandchildren placed well, and that is why she is working. She indicated that whatever she has would be passed unto her grandchildren since all her children are successfully married. 

She is asking for this loan to buy 1,000 GHS (Ghana cedis) worth of Coca-Cola, Sprite, Fanta and fruit juice. With the help of this loan, she hopes to improve her profits, because she will have more products to sell to her customers. 

Naomi's customers prefer her because she takes good care of her customers. She is very happy to keep working with ID-Ghana.

loans.use: To buy Coca-Cola, Sprite, Fanta and fruit juice.

loans.name: Kalsoum

texts.en: Kalsoum, 50, is a married lady; she has been successfully running a small general store in her house. She has eleven years of experience in this field.  She offers variety of grocery items at reasonable prices and has retained many customers who regularly shop at her store. She makes enough to provide for her family. To make her store fully stocked, she requested for a loan of 45,000 PKR, which she will use to buy rice, sugar and flour from the market at lower rates. In this way, she will be able to meet increasing demand consistently. She is in her fifth loan cycle and has a good repayment history. She wishes to utilize part of her revenues to increase her business capital.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar and flour from the market at lower rates.

loans.name: Asma

texts.en:
Asma is a 35-year-old married woman and mother of five. She is a hardworking mother who is helping her family by providing tailoring services in her community. She has been in this business for the past two years, and she knows the techniques of stitching very well. Her regular customers are her neighbors and members of the local community. Asma earns enough to lead a decent life. 

To help her continue operating her business, Asma has requested a loan of PKR 25,000 to buy a stock of threads in different colors and packs of zippers, buttons, and ribbons to meet the increasing demand for her services. In addition to repaying the loan, she will use part of the revenues to deal with personal expenses.

loans.use: to buy thread, zippers, buttons, and ribbons.

loans.name: Sarafina

texts.en:
Sarafina, age 26, sells vegetables and fruits in the town of Kitengela to earn an income. She has been engaged in this business for the past five years and currently makes a monthly income of 1,500 Kenya Shillings. She and her husband have five children.

This will be Sarafina's first loan term with KADET Ltd. She plans to use her loan funds to buy a new stock of cabbages, tomatoes, and potatoes, as well as fruits such as bananas, oranges, and mangoes to offer for sale. 

She will use the anticipated increased income to open a bigger grocery stall.

Sarafina hopes to grow her business, make more income, and be able to provide a good education for her children.

loans.use: to buy a new stock of cabbages, tomatoes, and potatoes, as well as fruits such as bananas, oranges, and mangoes to offer for sale

loans.name: Mariama Telly's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe de deux personnes en sein des femmes très braves et désireuses d’apporter un plus à leur foyer. Elles habitent toutes le même village. Il existe une parfaite solidarité entre les femmes. Elles font comme activité principale le  petit commerce et la fabrication de savon traditionnel.

Madame Mariama (debout à gauche en boubou jaune avec la main gauche levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette, elle est âgée de 49 ans, mariée et mère de six enfants dont quatre garçons. Elle est revendeuse de dérivé de pétrole à usage domestique. Elle achète des bidons de 20 litres à 18 000 F CFA au marché central de la commune pour la revente en bouteille d’un litre à 1 100 F CFA. A cette activité elle y ajoute la vente de divers produits à usage domestique : savon traditionnel, détergents et autres.

Ce nouveau prêt lui permettra d’acheter en quantité à savoir 10 bidons de 20 litres de pétrole et le reste de l’argent pour quels que lots de savon traditionnel.  

Les bénéfices lui permettront de contribuer sensiblement aux frais scolaires de ses enfants.
texts.en:
This group consists of two good and honest women who are eager to improve their families' living conditions.  They both live in the same village and there is true solidarity between them. Their main activity is small retail business and they also make traditional soap.

Mariama (standing in the left, wearing a yellow boubou and raising her hand), is the featured borrower.  She is 49 years old, married, and the mother of six children including four boys.  She resells petroleum by-products for domestic use.  She buys her merchandise in 20-liter cans at a price of 18,000 CFA francs at the central market of her commune and resells it in one-liter bottles at a price of 1,100 CFA francs.  Additionally, she also sells several household products such as traditional soap, detergents etc.

This new loan will help her to buy petroleum in bulk quantities (she will buy 10 cans, each containing 20 liters of petroleum).  With the remaining money, she will also buy a few packages of traditional soap.

With her profits, she will be able to significantly contribute to her children's school fees.

loans.use: to buy bulk quantities of petroleum (ten 20-liter cans) and some packages of traditional soap.

loans.name: Nune

texts.en:
Nune lives in Kapan with her son and daughter. Unfortunately Nune's husband has died several years ago and she alone and with great effort has brought up her children, both of whom are now students. Her son studies at the Yerevan State Economics University in the Department of International Economics Relations (paid division) and her daughter is a student of the Marketing Department at the same university. They both are very clever and prudent persons and they understand only educated and clever society can create a future for their country.

Nune herself is a teacher. She graduated from Yerevan State Linguistic University. For a long time she has worked at the school as a Russian Language and Literature teacher. Now she works as a secretary at the Syunik regional administration office. It is already Nune's second Kiva loan and like the first one this time Nune again needs money to pay for her sons tuition fees for the second semester.

loans.use: To pay for her son's tuition fees for the second semester

loans.name: Wilfrida

texts.en:
Wilfrida is 57 years old, married, and has 4 children. She sells fish in Oloitoktok town and has been in this business for four years. She currently makes a monthly income of 5,500 Kenyan shillings. 

This will be her second loan with KADET LTD, and she plans to use the loan to buy more stock of fish to sell. Since the demand for fish in the area is high, she anticipates earning more profit and further adding to her stock.

Wilfrida hopes to become successful in the fish-selling business and to be able to supply her family's basic needs.

loans.use: to buy more stock of fish to sell.

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mohammed is a 23-year-old man living in Aden, Yemen. Mohammed's business is a grocery store, which he started one year ago when he was partnered with someone else. He worked hard as much as possible to take his friend's share. He was able to gain many customers and he is now inspired to expand his capital and income by purchasing all the grocery items needed by members of his neighborhood. To do this, He has taken a youth loan of 200,000 Yemeni Rials (YER) from Kiva partner AMB for purchasing all the required grocery items. In the future, He hopes to expand his business by opening another store.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items for his business

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en: Cynthia, 27, is married and has four children, all of whom attend school. She will use her loan to buy more sorghum for sale. The profits from the business will be used to make more savings for the better future of her business.

loans.use: To buy more sorghum for sale

loans.name: Rev George

texts.en:
George is a 35-year-old man from Usenge location, which is found in the Western part of Kenya. He supports three people in his family and is married to Maurine, who is also a business lady within the same region. George has two children who are five and three years old respectively.

He uses his donkey and a handcart to supply water to the neighborhood. He has done this business for the last three years to generate a monthly income of KES 12000. He has applied for his third loan with KADET LTD, which he will use to purchase another handcart. He will use the anticipated profit to start another business.

His dream is to have a stable business and take care of his family.

loans.use: To purchase another handcart for his water supply business.

loans.name: Mrika

texts.en:
Mrika has just invested in a store in a neighborhood of a city in northwestern part of the country. Her intention was from the very beginning to sell used shoes and the loan she is requesting at the moment will be used for this purpose. In the past, she had requested a loan from different institutions that operate in the country, but she was unsuccessful until recently when she came to VFA. It was there that she was told that despite the fact that she was not eligible for regular loans, she was eligible for startup loans through Kiva, and she literally was ecstatic.

Mrika is fifty one years old and has three children, who are still in school.

loans.use: to buy used shoes to resell

loans.name: Kosar

texts.en:
Kosar is a 46-year-old married woman. She has been selling vegetables for the past ten years with the support of her husband, who is shown in the photo. Her husband buys stocks of vegetables from the market and then they sell them to the people of their community. They earn a reasonable amount of money to support their family. Kosar is a loving mother of four children and is responsible for their food, health, and education. The couple is trying hard to fulfill their basic necessities of life. 

For the improvement of the business, Kosar contacted Kashf Foundation to apply for a loan of PKR 20,000 to purchase sacks of different kinds of vegetables such as onions, tomatoes, and potatoes. This will be her third loan. She wishes to use part of her profits for the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of vegetables to sell

loans.name: Cabir

texts.en:
Cabir is a 25-year-old married man and father of one daughter. Cabir does not have a higher education and because of that he has been selling fruits and vegetables for past eight years. He is growing vegetables in his own yard and his wife also helps him in this business. He says, even though this business is very hard, together with his wife he has been handling the business without any difficulty. His income from vegetable and fruit sales is 150 AZN. He has more plans for the future, such as to get more lands for cultivation.  Cabir is looking forward to the increased sales in the coming summer, because people purchase fruit a lot.
Nowadays he needs a loan of 2000 AZN. This loan is for the purpose of getting new fertilizers and seeds. It will help him to grow more vegetables and fruits in order to get more revenue in the coming summer, which will help him to support his family’s needs. He has a good loan history. This is his fourth loan.

loans.use: to purchase new fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is 48 years old, married and has 8 children. He is a farmer in Makueni town where he plants maize, beans and mango fruits to sell. He has been in this business for the past 10 years. He currently makes a monthly income of 15,000 Kenya Shillings. 

This will be his first loan term with KADET LTD and he plans to use the amount to buy fertilizer and farm equipment for use in planting. He will use the generated profits to provide for the basic needs of his family. 

He hopes to improve his farming methods and become one of the best farmers in the area.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm equipment for use in planting.

loans.name: Dali

texts.en:
Dali is 65-year-old retired woman. She lives in the Borjomi district with her retired mother and retired aunt. Dali requested loans from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan requests were rejected every time because of her low income and the family's poor living conditions.

All three members of the family are getting pensions of 125 Lari per month. This is the only source of income for them. Dali requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Dali has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. 

The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as "high risk borrowers" because of their low income. 

With her credit Dali will purchase all the needed materials to finish her house renovation. The family owns a 3 floor house, and already had some savings which were used start the house renovation. Dali plans to rent out seasonally the first and second floors of the house to tourists. The family will earn an additional income with this business and they will be able to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to finish renovating her house so the first two floors can be rented

loans.name: Naziran

texts.en:
Naziran, 36, is a married woman. She is a very talented lady who excels in her work of stitching. She has gotten a lot of appreciation from her community. She accepted the fact that if her husband works alone for their family, they will not be able to meet the expenses of their household, which include the educational needs of children. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

She has now requested a loan of 20,000 PKR to purchase more reels of threads, packs of buttons, zippers and lace in various colors. With these materials, she will be able to meet increasing demand consistently. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She is in her 3rd loan cycle and has a good repayment history. Naziran hopes to grow her business and dreams of giving a high-quality education to her children.

loans.use: to purchase more reels of thread, packs of buttons, zippers, and lace in various colors.

loans.name: Kujtim

texts.en:
Kujtim is engaged in an animal husbandry business. He is in his early sixties and has been engaged in his business for over 20 years. "There is nothing else I can do better than this," he tells us. "I have been selling milk and other animal produce to the locals and dairy farms, and the income I have generated hasn’t been that bad. I am very grateful." 

Kujtim is married, and his children are in their twenties. One of them is attending university.

This will be Kujtim's first loan from VFA and Kiva lenders. When he applied, he was thrilled at the prospect of having his profile published on Kiva. He is requesting a loan in the amount of 100,000 Albanian Lek.  

He will use his loan funds to buy goats.

loans.use: to buy goats

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie, age 46, sells charcoal at the local market to earn an income. She lives with her husband and children in the West Point area, which has the most populated market in Montserrado County.

Annie started her business with money given to her by her mother.  She sells her wares six days a week from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m., and she uses a shared taxi to get her goods to her table. She enjoys her business because she likes interacting with her customers.

Annie is requesting a loan to in order to purchase charcoal to offer for sale. Her goal for the future is to build a house for her children.  

She would like to offer her thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal to offer for sale

loans.name: Koba

texts.en:
Koba is 35 years old. He lives in the Rustavi District with his wife, 10-year-old son, and parents. Koba requested loans from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan requests were rejected every time because of his low income and the family's poor living conditions.

Koba works as a driver at a private company and gets a monthly income. His wife works as a nurse at a local kindergarten. It is hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category.

Koba requested loan from Credo to start up a family business. Koba has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. 

The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as "high risk borrowers" because of their low income. 

With his credit Koba will purchase a car and serve local people as a taxi driver. He has a rich experience of being a driver and hopes that this will be profitable for his family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase a car and serve local people as a taxi driver

loans.name: Mariana Del Carmen

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Amistad, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, por ser una zona con gran vegetación.

En este lugar vive la señora Mariana, tiene 56 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos mayores de edad e independientes. Su esposo es comerciante.

Doña Mariana junto con el esposo tienen un negocio de venta de ropa, bisutería y varios artículos de bazar, su marido vende por la ciudad y fuera de ella ya que también visita otras ciudades como Calceta y Bahía, ella mientras tanto vende en su casa lugar donde sus clientes más conocidos.  Su esposo se dedica a esta actividad desde que era soltero y continua hasta la actualidad ya que es la forma para sacar adelante a su familia.

Este crédito es para comprar ropa, bisutería y productos de bazar. Lleva más de 10  años  en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque los créditos salen rápido y sin tantos requisitos. 

Su sueño es tener un almacén.
texts.en:
The Amistad banco comunal meets every 15 days in the city of Tosagua. This place is known for being very dynamic, where the majority of its habitants work in agriculture or by raising animals. The area has a lot of vegetation.

Mariana lives here. She is 56 years old, married, and has three adult children who live independently. Her husband is a vendor.

Mariana and her husband have a business selling clothes, jewelry, and various household products. Her husband sells in the city and he also goes outside the city, visiting Calceta and Bahía. She sells from home to familiar customers. Her husband has worked in this business since he was single and continues with it now to move his family forward.

This loan is to buy clothes, jewelry, and household products. She has been part of this communal bank for over 10 years and she likes that the loans come quickly without many requirements.

Her dream is to have a store.

loans.use: to buy clothes, jewelry, and household products.

loans.name: Al-Noory Group

texts.en:
This group is called Al-Noory and is made up of four ladies who live in Aden, Yemen. This is a group of hard-working women who work as hard as they can in order to offer better living conditions to their families. Together, they are requesting a loan in the amount of 150,000 YER. 

Fatima, age 28, is the leader of this group. She and her husband live in a small house in Aden, and she expended a lot of effort and saved a lot of money with her husband in order to obtain and set up her house. Her goal is to complete construction of her house. She has therefore requested a youth loan of 60,000 in order to buy construction supplies. 

Fatima and the other members of this group (Samah, Dhakr, Asma, and Khadija) thank Kiva lenders for financing their efforts.

loans.use: to buy construction supplies for her house

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is 55 years old and lives in the West Point area which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is married, and she does not know how to read or write. She has eight children aged between 30 and 24 who live at home, and only two attending school. She described herself as a hardworking woman. 

For the past seven years she has been selling soft drinks in the local market, she sells six days in a week from 7AM to 5PM,. She likes her business because she has a lot of customers, and she started this business with money given to her by her husband. She uses a shared taxi every time to get her soft drinks to her business spot. 

Edith is requesting a loan to purchase more soft drinks for her business. Her dream is to build a house for her children.  She would like to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase more soft drinks for her business.

loans.name: Michael's Group

texts.en:
This group is made up of four members. One of them, Michael, is a 40-year-old married man and has one child. He has been selling clothing for eight consecutive years and has been a member of the institution for one year.

He started sales of second-hand clothing with a little money he had mobilized and now he needs to grow the business, therefore decided to request a loan to grow his business. He needs GHS 400 to buy one bale of men's jeans to sell to his customers.

Julian is 38 years old and she sells clothing; Princilla is 33 and sells 'kenkey' (corn paste); and Carmen is 53 and she sells flour and margarine. They need a total amount of GHS 1600 to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy one bale of second-hand men's jeans

loans.name: Hovhannes

texts.en: Hovhannes lives in a small city, Gavar, which is in the Gegharkunik area. He is married and has a son who is a student, and a daughter who is already married. Hovhannes’ wife works at Gavar State Agricultural College. Hovhannes has a vocational education with a specialty in radiotechnics. For several years he worked at his specialty, but now he works as a driver and is also engaged in farming. He has five cows and six calves. Since their farm cattle are few, their income is not enough for their family needs. Hovhannes considers that although his son is studying at Yerevan and that life in the city may seem to him more colorful and easier than in their village, he wants his son to be engaged in farming and be close to their village and to their land. Hovhannes wishes to enlarge his farm and he asks a loan of 900,000 Armenian drams to buy a cow and a bull and a lot of animal fodder which will keep his animals safe and fed in the winter months.

loans.use: To buy a cow and a bull and a lot of animal fodder

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice lives in the Litein area of Kenya. She has six children and has been doing this work for 15 years. Her primary income sources are milk and crops. She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: “Farming” Her biggest challenge is “Insufficient funds.” Animals on the farm have been given the name “Lelkina.” Alice was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: “Because of grace period.” This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required microfinance training session: “That they also finance assets.” Her highest monthly expense is for farming costs. When asked “How will this loan benefit her family”, Alice replied “In expanding dairy farming in order to increase the benefits.” As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Alice owns the following: “cow, poultry” but does not own “pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile”. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household “mosquito net” but does not have “electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD”.

loans.use: to purchase poultry for her farm.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is 40 years old and lives in the West Point area, which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is unmarried, and she has three children between the ages of 12 and 20 years old. Only two are in school, and they all live at home. She completed 10 grades before starting her business. Comfort describes herself as a hardworking woman. For the past 10 years, she has been selling oil, onions, eggs, and other items from a table in the local market. She sells six days a week from 8AM to 6PM. She enjoys her business because of the flow of customers, and she started this business with money given to her by her mother. She often uses a shared taxi to get her goods to her table. Comfort requests a loan to purchase oil, onions, eggs, and other items for her business. She plans to build a house for her children. She would like to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase oil, onions, eggs, and other items to sell

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en:
Solomon is 43 years old. He lives in Kvareli District with his wife, Tamar, and mother, who is provided with a retirement pension. Solomon requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time because of low income and family’s poor living conditions. 

Solomon is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, they have two pigs and 0.5 hectare of agricultural land, where maize is grown. He sells the harvested maize at local markets. Tamar works as a nurse at a local kindergarten. It is hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Solomon requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Solomon has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit, Solomon will purchase a car and serve local people as a taxi driver. After purchasing a car, he will be able to increase the income of his family. Part of the profit will be reinvested in the agricultural business. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase a car and serve local people as a taxi driver.

loans.name: Twitezimbere Group

texts.fr:
Consolatte fait partie du groupe Twitezimbere et habite à  Gutega. Elle  a 60 ans et est mariée à  Dieudonné, un fonctionnaire. Ensemble ils ont 3 enfants,  âgés de  14  à 19 ans, tous étudient.  

Elle fait le commerce de  la bière industrielle depuis 13  ans. 

Elle est à son dix-neuvième  crédit à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle obtient, elle va  augmenter son capital et acheter  une grande quantité de bière industrielle à revendre pour gagner plus.

Le gain de son commerce, lui permet de payer les frais de scolarité des ses enfants, nourrir la famille et assurer les soins de santé.
texts.en:
Consolatte is a member of the Twitezimbere group and she lives in Gitega.  She is 60 years old and married to Dieudonné, a civil servant.  Together, they have three children between the ages of 14 and 19.  All their children are in school.

Consolatte has been selling commercial beer for 13 years.

This is her 19th loan with Turame.  With this loan, financed by Kiva, she will increase her capital and buy a large quantity of commercial beer for resale, in order to make more money.

With the earnings from her business, she is able to pay her children's school fees, to feed her family and to take care of healthcare costs.

loans.use: to buy a large quantity of commercial beer for resale.

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma, age 58, is a housewife. She adores her family, and her husband works very hard so that his family can have a good and respectable life. Her husband owns a furniture shop in the main market which is the only source of income for the family. 

Salma is requesting a loan from Kiva partner BRAC Pakistan with the goal of improving her husband's business. He will use the loan to purchase wood for manufacturing furniture. With the profits expected from this loan, he intends to expand his business so that he can eventually construct a small house for his family. Salma hopes that the loan will be helpful for her husband's business. She is thankful to Kiva lenders and to BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To purchase wood for manufacturing furniture.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en: Razia, age 36, is a housewife. She adores her family, and her husband works very hard so that his family can have a good and respectable life. Her husband is a milk seller. This business is the only source of income for the family. Razia is requesting a loan from Kiva partner BRAC Pakistan with the goal of improving her husband's business. He will use the loan to purchase a buffalo to sell milk. Razia hopes that the loan will be helpful for her husband's business. She is thankful to Kiva lenders and to BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to purchase a buffalo to sell milk

loans.name: Bushra

texts.en: Bushra is a 44-year-old married woman. She works on a winding machine, wrapping threads and yarn onto spools and reels. She has been doing this for about five years. She offers handmade threads in various colors, and she is famous in her community for providing good quality thread. She is a mother of three daughters and is trying hard to meet their needs, including food, health care, clothing, and education. She is applying for a loan of PKR 40,000 from Kashf Foundation, which she will use to buy bundles of yarn and threads in various colors, and some tools to use with her machinery. In this way, she would be able to increase her sales, which will ultimately help in generating more cash. She hopes to have a good experience with the new loan.

loans.use: to buy supplies and equipment for winding thread and yarn onto spools and reels.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa, age 39, sells fish to earn a living. She lives in the West Point area, which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is the single mother of four children between the ages of five and 19 years old. Two are presently enrolled in school and three of them still live at home. Hawa herself  was unable to go to school.

Hawa started her business with money given to her by her mother. She describes herself as a hard-working woman. She works six days per week from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m., and she uses a shared taxi to bring her wares to her table. She enjoys her business because of the interactions with her customers.

She is requesting a loan in order to purchase fish to offer for sale. Her goal for the future is to build a house for her children.  

She would like to offer her thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for her business,

loans.name: Charo

texts.en: Charo is a 49-year-old fruit vendor in Kongowea, Mombasa. He is married and a father who supports six children of his own. He has been in this business for the last twenty years. This marks Charo's second loan from KADET Ltd to finance his business. He will use the loan to buy mangoes for resale, and he will repay his loan from the anticipated proceeds. He hopes to have a successful life in the future.

loans.use: to purchase mangoes for resale.

loans.name: Tigran

texts.en:
Tigran and his family live in the village Tsovazard which is in the Gavar area. Tigran is married and has two children. His wife is unemployed, and she takes care of their sons. For several years, Tigran worked abroad in the Russian Federation where he engaged in building and reconstructing work. During that time, he was working hard to support his family financially, but being so far from his family was very difficult for him so he came back and he and his wife became engaged in farming together. They have two cows, two bulls, two heifers, two calves, eight sheep, and two pigs. Tigran plans to begin selling a lot of dairy products from their house so he needs to increase the number of cattle on his farm. 
He asks for a loan of 900,000 Armenian drams to buy several calves and fodder for his animals. He will be very grateful to Kiva lenders if they are willing to support him.

loans.use: To buy several calves and fodder for his animals

loans.name: Adela María

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Amistad, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, por ser una zona con gran vegetación.

En este lugar vive la señora María, tiene 56 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene un hijo mayor de edad e independiente. El marido se dedica al comercio. 

Doña María con su esposo se dedican a preparar almuerzos y bocadillos, él se encarga de ir a entregar o vender por la localidad, ella también prepara almuerzos para varias instituciones y  en las tardes hace pastelillos, empanadas de plátano con queso , carne o pollo las cuales son muy deliciosas.  Llevan  más de 20 años  dedicados a esta actividad que les permite salir adelante.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar víveres para preparar los alimentos. Lleva más de 15 años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que le dan con los créditos. 

Su sueño es tener buena salud ella y su marido.
texts.en:
The Amistad communal bank meets every 15 days in the city of Tosagua. This place is known for being very dynamic, where a majority of the habitants work in agriculture or by raising cattle. The area has a lot of vegetation.

Maria, 56, lives here. She is in a civil union and has one adult child who lives independently. Her husband is a vendor.

Maria and her husband work by making lunches and sandwiches. He is in charge of gong out and delivering or selling in the area. She also makes lunches for various institutions and in the afternoons she makes cupcakes and plantain empanadas with cheese, meat, or chicken, which are very delicious. They have had this business for over 20 years and it allows them to move forward.

This loan will be used to buy supplies for making meals. She has been part of the communal bank for 15 years and she likes the help they provide with the loans.

Her dream is for her and her husband to be healthy.

loans.use: to buy supplies

loans.name: Vladimer

texts.en:
Vladimer is 65 years old. He lives in Tbilisi, the capital city of Georgia, with his wife, daughter and son-in-law. Vladimer requested loans from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan requests were rejected every time because of his low income and the family's poor living conditions.

Vladimer works as a driver on the minibus line and gets a monthly income. His wife is a teacher at a local school. It is hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category.

Vladimer requested loan from Credo to start up a family business. Vladimer has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as "high risk borrowers" because of their low income. 

With his credit Vladimer will purchase milking cows and hens. As he has a house in the Martkopi district, he has decided to begin an agricultural business there. After purchasing cows and hens, he will begin a husbandry business. In particular, he will sell dairy products and eggs. The income will be reinvested in the business, which will be expanded in the future. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase milking cows and hens

loans.name: Razia
