texts.en: Razia is a 40-year-old married woman. She has been actively involved in the business of making costume jewelry for three years. The business has great potential for growth, and Razia is trying hard to support her family through her business, as this business is the only source of earning of her family. She is a mother of four children; none of them are going to school. She wishes to send them to school by trying to increase her earnings to afford the educational expenses of her children. In order to meet the orders on time and boost her sales, she applied for a loan of PKR 35,000 to buy raw materials, such as silver and dozens of artificial gems and pearls. She hopes to increase her net income and wishes to use it to provide a good quality education to her children.

loans.use: to buy raw materials, such as silver and dozens of artificial gems and pearls, for her jewelry-making business.

loans.name: Ghulam-Zuhra

texts.en: Ghulam-Zuhra is a vigorous 44-year-old lady; she has been sewing clothes for many years. She sews for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. She knows the techniques of sewing very well. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns enough to afford a decent life. But due to a lack of funds, she is not able to complete the orders of her customers on time. For this reason, she applied for a loan of PKR 20,000 to buy a stock of thread in various colors and packets of zippers, buttons, and the like. She has two children and is striving hard to meet their needs, including food, clothing, and health care. She hopes to increase her income and wants to use part of the revenues on the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: to buy a stock of thread in various colors and packets of zippers, buttons, and the like.

loans.name: Shameem

texts.en: Shameem is 50 years old, an energetic married woman. She is the mother of four children; two of them are school-going, and one of her sons is a government employee, but due to his low income he is not able to cover the needs of his large family. Shameem has been happily running a business of milk sales for the past fifteen years, to contribute to her family income. She now has one buffalo in milk and sells the milk to many of her neighbors, along with butter and cheese that she makes from the milk. Her business is good enough for her to lead a decent life. For the further improvement of her business, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of PKR 25,000 to buy one more buffalo. She hopes to get an increase in milk production capacity, which will ultimately help in generating more cash.

loans.use: to purchase one more buffalo.

loans.name: Musarat

texts.en: Musarat is 26 years old, an energetic married woman. She has been actively involved in the business of animal sales for the past four years with the support of her husband, who is a laborer whose income is not sufficient to cover the needs of his family. Musarat took the initiative to contribute to her family’s income. She buys animals (baby goats and calves) at low prices and raises them, and then her husband sells them in the market at higher prices. She has gradually improved her business with the support of Kashf Foundation; she has now applied for a loan of PKR 20,000 to buy one more goat. She is in her second loan cycle, with a good repayment history. She hopes to grow her business and dreams of providing a better standard of living to her family.

loans.use: to purchase one more goat.

loans.name: Teimuraz

texts.en:
Teimuraz is 41 years old. He lives in the small village of Telavi District with his wife and 20-year-old son. Teimuraz requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected each time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

Teimuraz is an auto car artisan and repairs cars. His son works as a driver at a private company. It is hardly enough to provide food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Teimuraz requested loan from Credo to start up a family business. Teimuraz has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. With the received credit, Teimuraz will open an auto car wash. As he is a well-known artisan in his village and has a good number of clients, he thinks that his new business will be profitable. The profit will be reinvested in the same business. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to open an auto car wash

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Monica's Group

texts.en:
Monica's group is composed of five hardworking women. Monica is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyenjojo in the Mubende region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past two years, Monica has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar, milk, and bread. 

To help expand her business, Monica has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more items such as milk, soup, and bread to sell in the store, and will help Monica to generate greater profits and take care of her family's needs. Monica hopes that in the future she will be able to buy land and build a house. 

Monica is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, as well as a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase for more items such as milk, soup, and bread to sell in her store

loans.name: Armen

texts.en:
Armen is 52 years old. He and his family (including his father and mother, who are retired, his wife and his son) live in Yerevan. Armen’s son helps him very much, and sooner or later he will take over his father’s business.

For many years Armen worked in the tax system, but the low income and great changes in that system made Armen radically change the sphere of his work. He began a new business, together with his friend. They rented a small space, where they used to sell live fish. But now, Armen works separately, and he has enriched the services of his business. Armen not only sells the fish, but he also has all the needed equipment to prepare good and tasty fish on the grill. Armen’s stall is very famous and visited daily by the people living nearby, and also by those who especially want to taste fish prepared by Armen.

The income from the fish business satisfies Armen, but he plans to enlarge both the assortment of fish and his business services. Armen asks a loan of 670,000 Armenian drams. He will use part of this loan to rent a car for the delivery of prepared fish, and part to buy a lot of fish to sell.

loans.use: To rent a car for the delivery of prepared fish, and to buy a lot of fish to sell

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en: Samwel is a Kiva borrower who describes himself as intelligent. He has taken a loan of Kes 20,000 to buy a water tank that will benefit six members of the household. The family faces a challenge of access to clean safe water. The tank will enable them to store rain water and also distilled water for domestic use. His source of income is a quarry where he carves building stones to sell. He hopes that in the future he will be a distributor of building materials. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy a water tank

loans.name: Alba Aracely

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Amistad, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, por ser una zona con gran vegetación.

En este lugar vive la señora Alba, tiene 50 años de edad está separada pero de esa relación tiene un hijo mayor de edad e independiente. Ella vive con unos hermanos.

Doña Alba para ganarse la vida se dedica al comercio, tiene un local en el centro de la ciudad donde vende, teléfonos celulares, zapatillas de niñas y de mujeres, bisutería, maní molido, quesos, sodas y varias bebidas más, allí trabaja todos los días con la ayuda de una chica a quien le paga un sueldo mensual. Tiene este negocio por más de 15 años y siempre la ha ido muy bien.

Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: zapatillas, bisutería, quesos, maní molida  entre otras cosas. Lleva más de 6 años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por los beneficios que recibe de la institución. 

Su sueño es  tener su local propio ya que arrienda el local y esto se le lleva parte de sus ganancias.
texts.en:
The Amistad communal bank meets every 15 days in the city of Tosagua. This place is known for being very dynamic, where a majority of the habitants work in agriculture or by raising animals. The area has a lot of vegetation. 

Alba, 50, lives here. She is separated but has one adult child who lives independently. She lives with siblings.

Alba works as a vendor. She has a shop in the center of the city where she sells cell phones, children's and women's shoes, jewelry, peanut butter, cheese, soda, and other drinks. She works there every day with the help of a girl who she pays a monthly salary. She has had this business for over 15 years and it has always gone well.

This loan will be used to buy merchandise such as shoes, jewelry, cheese, peanut butter, and other items. She has been part of the communal bank for over 6 years and she likes the benefits that the institution provides.

Her dream is to have her own shop since she currently rents and this takes away some of her earnings.

loans.use: to buy shoes, jewelry, cheese, and peanut butter

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, which is an area that does not suffer from dry seasons. She has five children and has been doing this work for ten years. Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, tea, crops, transportation services, and personal business. She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: “Wheat, tea, maize (corn), cows.” Her biggest challenges are “Pests, climate change.” Animals on the farm have been given the name of “Nyan'era.” Hellen was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: “Because it deals with farming and am an interested farmer.” This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required microfinance training session: “Improve living standards if the loans are used wisely.” Her highest monthly expense is for school fees. When asked “How will this loan benefit her family”, Hellen replied “Will help her cater for both their needs.” As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Hellen owns the following: “cow, poultry, pump, motorcycle” but does not own “pig, bicycle, automobile”. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household “mosquito net, running water, TV” but does not have “electricity, solar power, sewing machine, DVD”. 
Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Albina

texts.en: Albina is an Egyptian Albanian, married, and has five children; they all live in a main city in the southeastern part of the country. She has been selling new items, mostly door-to-door, during these past six years, and with this loan she will buy goods to resell. Kindly note that, since there is no stable place for her business, she chose to be photographed at home with her adorable granddaughter. “I love my grandkids and I am happy that my activity gives me some space to spend time with them and also I make money through it to buy them things they need,” said Albina. “I also make free time to go to church as well, because I am a Christian devotee,” she continued saying.

loans.use: to buy new items to resell door-to-door.

loans.name: Rudina

texts.en:
Rudina, age 22, sells second-hand clothing to earn an income. She has been engaged in this business for four years. She is a member of the vulnerable ethnic Egyptian community, and she lives in the suburb of a main city in Albania known for being home to a large number of Egyptian residents. She and her husband have a two-year-old child.

In addition to her clothing sales venture, Rudina has finished nursing school, and she practices these skills as well. "I am busy and I like it," she tells us. "I work constantly in order to offer to good things to my family. There may be things we need, but still I am grateful for what we have at the moment."

Rudina has requested a loan in order to buy used clothing items to offer for sale. As for the future, she says, "My husband and I have planned to build a house, and to achieve this we must work hard. My husband is trying to start up a little car washing activity. Let's see what happens!"

loans.use: to buy second-hand clothing to offer for sale

loans.name: Mamie

texts.en:
Mamie is 32 years old and lives in the area of West Point, which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She lives together with her fiance, who is a not working now. They have two children aged 10 and 3, both of whom are in school and live at home. She described herself as a hardworking person. She completed grade 9.

For the past 5 years she has been selling bread. She likes her business because of the business she receives from her customers. She started this business with money given to her by her fiance. She uses a taxi to get her goods to her spot. She is requesting a loan to purchase more bread for her business. Eventually, she plans to buy a piece of land and build a house. She would like to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia to enable small businesspeople to increase their business volume.

loans.use: to purchase more bread for her business.

loans.name: Gaudy Vanessa

texts.es: Gaudy es una mujer de 32 años, madre de tres hijos, originaria de Managua, ella se dedica a la venta de ropa y cosméticos desde muy joven, cuando tomo experiencia se dedicó a vender mercadería por cuenta propia su único apoyo es su esposo quien trabaja de bar man en una disco. Está solicitando este préstamo para comprar ropa, perfumes, cosméticos, ya que tiene mercadería encargada y necesita el financiamiento para poder realizar su compra al  por mayor y vender.  Ella estima que el crédito le dará satisfacción en la demanda de sus productos y en un futuro incrementar el volumen de mercadería,su meta es terminar su carrera de Marketing y hacer crecer el negocio.
texts.en:
Gaudy is a 32 year old mother of three who is a native of Managua. She has been selling clothing and cosmetics since she was very young. Once she had gained experience she began to sell merchandise on her own. Her only support is her husband, who works as a bartender in a disco. 

She is seeking this loan in order to purchase clothing, perfumes and cosmetics since she has merchandise on order and needs financing to be able to complete her purchase wholesale and sell it. She thinks that the loan will give her success in the demand for her products and in the future will increase the volume of her merchandise. Her goal is to finish her training in marketing and to make her business grow.

loans.use: to buy clothing, perfumes and cosmetics

loans.name: Gani

texts.en:
Gani is an Egyptian Albanian who began practicing welding at a very young age. He is in his early sixties now and living in a rural village, unlike the majority of his community members who have chosen to live in suburbia.

“With the collapse of the communist era in the 90s, I thought it would be much better to live in a village, financially and otherwise. So I did, and never regret it. While I was working as a welder, I also took care of my other activity, livestock.” said Gani. "I sell milk and other animal produce to the local market of a nearby city and I make enough money, thank God,” Gani continued. 

Gani wants to buy a milk cow with this loan.

loans.use: to buy a milk cow

loans.name: Neamie

texts.en:
Neamie is 29 years old and lives in the West Point area which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is single, and she stopped her education at grade 6. She described herself as a hardworking woman. 

For the past seven years she has been selling soft drinks in the local market; she sells six days in a week from 7AM to 5PM. She likes her business because she has a lot of customers, and she started this business with money given to her by her mother. She uses a shared taxi every time to get her goods to her business shop.

She is requesting a loan to purchase soft drinks for her business. She plans to build a house for her children.  She would like to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks for her business

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience is 36 years old and lives in the West Point area, which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is single, and she has three children aged between 16 and 10. The children are presently in school, and all three of them live at home. Patience, herself, was unable to go to school. She describes herself as a hardworking woman.

For the past two years, she has been selling soft drinks in the local market. She sells six days a week, from 9AM to 6PM. She likes her business because of the way customers buy from her. Patience started this business with money given to her by her mother. She uses a shared taxi every time, to get her goods to her business spot. She is requesting a loan to purchase more soft drinks to resell at her business. Her plan is to build a house for her children.  She would like to say "thanks," to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase more soft drinks to resell at her business

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex is a resident of Nyambogome, Kebisoni in the Rukungiri District. He was born in 1983, so he is 30 years old. He is a married man and a father to three children. Only one of them attends school. He also has one dependent who is an orphan.

Alex completed the basic level (primary level) of school and dropped out due financial problems since he grew up in a bigger family of more than 10 children. So, with that hardship, he then decided to begin a business.

His main business is coffee trade, but he also has additional income from boda-boda driving (providing transportation services to passengers). He has been in this business since 2006.

He therefore needed financial assistance to boost his business and achieve his dream of stabilizing his business and educating his children. This led him to access UGAFODE Microfinance Limited (MDI) services, which have taken him to a greater level. His main challenge is competition from other coffee traders and that’s why he has to improve his production so as to out-compete them.

He describes himself as hardworking and honest, and therefore, he can be trusted with the organization's funds.

loans.use: To buy coffee to sell

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort, age 35, prepares and sells rice dishes and soup at her local market to earn a living. She lives in the West Point area, which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is the unmarried mother of a nine-year-old child who is enrolled in school and lives at home. Comfort herself did not have the opportunity to go to school. 

Comfort describes herself as a hard-working woman. She started her business four years ago with money given to her by her fiancé. She sells her wares six days a week from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m., and she uses a shared taxi to bring her goods to her market table. She likes her business because she enjoys the interaction with her customers. 

Comfort is requesting a loan in order to purchase ingredients such as rice, pepper, fish, meat, and onions for her business. In the future, she plans to build a house for her child. 

She would like to offer her thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients such as rice, pepper, fish, meat, and onions for her business

loans.name: Furigyesio

texts.en:
Furigyesio was born in 1970 at Mabanga – Buyanja, Rukungiri District. He is married with nine children, with six of them in school.

Furigyesio is a butcher, a job he started in 2006 to supplement his income of agriculture so as to meet his family financial obligations. He joined UGAFODE Microfinance Limited (MDI) in 2009 for financial assistance with the aim of improving and increasing the family income. Furigyesio has been taking loans which he has been using to run his business and pay school fees for his children.

He is taking this loan to boost his business so as to serve more clients and increase on his income. He goes ahead to praise UGAFODE Microfinance Limited (MDI) for the financial assistance it has advanced to him thus enabling him to educate his children and sustain his business.

loans.use: To buy goats for slaughter and later sell the meat

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is a young and nice lady; she is 31 years old and the only bread-winner in her big family. Stella lives in the village of Tsovazard, which is in Gegharkunik region. She lives with her husband, their small daughter, and her parents-in-law, who are retired. Stella has a higher education; she has graduated from Gavar State University. Now she works at their village municipality, as a computer operator. Stella is also engaged in farming and agriculture, in which her husband helps her. They keep three cows, three calves, ten sheep, ten lambs, and ten chickens. They also have a plot of land, where they cultivate beans, tomatoes and greens, and they have several apple trees. Most of these they use for family consumption, and the only produce from their land that they manage to sell is apples.

This is Stella’s first deal with Kiva and Nor Horizon. She asks a loan of 500,000 Armenian drams, which she will use to buy one cow, two piglets, and a lot of animal fodder. She hopes that this loan will help her to improve her family's living conditions, significantly.

loans.use: To buy one cow, two piglets, and a lot of animal fodder

loans.name: Tawah

texts.en:
Tawah is 35 years old and lives in the West Point area which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is unmarried, and she was unable to go to school. She has three children aged between 20 and 7; they are in school and live at home. She described herself as a hardworking woman.

For the past four years she has been selling cold water and soft drinks in the local market. She sells six days in a week from 7AM to 6PM, and she likes her business because of the way customers buy from her. She started this business with money given to her by her fiancee. She uses a shared taxi every time to get her goods to her business spot. She is requesting a loan to purchase more cold water and soft drinks for her business. She plans to build a house for her children.  She would like to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase more cold water and soft drinks for her business

loans.name: Assata

texts.en:
Assata is 30 years old and lives in the West Point area which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is married, and she was unable to go to school.  She has three children aged between 10 and 6; they are in school and live at home. She described herself as a hardworking woman.

For the past four years she has been selling rice, toothpaste, soap, oil, etc. in the local market. She sells six days in a week from 7AM to 6PM. She likes her business because of the way customers buy from her, and she started this business with money given to her by her husband. She uses a shared taxi every time to get her goods to her business spot. She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice, toothpaste, soap, oil, etc. for her business. She plans to build a house for her children.  She would like to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, toothpaste, soap, oil, etc. for her business

loans.name: Massa

texts.en:
Massa, age 36, sells such items as rice, cola, sugar, and oil at the local market to earn an income. She lives with her husband and their three children in the West Point area, which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. The children are between the ages of seven and 16 years, and are all enrolled in school. Massa herself did not have the opportunity to go to school.

She describes herself as a hard-working woman. She started her business four years ago with money given to her by her husband. She sells six days a week from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m., using a shared taxi to bring her goods to the market. She likes her business because she enjoys the interactions with her customers. 

Massa is requesting a loan in order to purchase goods such as rice, cola, sugar, and oil for her business. In the future, she plans to build a house for her children.  

She would like to offer her thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase goods such as rice, cola, sugar, and oil for her business

loans.name: Kinepna Group

texts.en:
Kinepna is a ten-member group of tribal women in the hilly regions of Manipur, which is situated in the Northeastern part of India. The group is represented by Helam who, by profession, is a tailor in the village. She is pictured in the photograph with her right hand raised. Helam is married and blessed with two sons and her husband provides satellite television connections in the village. 

Helam had once started a tailoring business in the past but due to some family problem, she had to close down the shop. However, the income her husband generates from the satellite TV business was not enough to provide for all the family's expenses. So, she decided to start tailoring in the village once again, and though she did not get a huge amount of profit, she said that she is able to save some for her sons' schooling expenses and other monthly family expenses. 

She started the tailoring business in 2011, and she said that she is able to save some from her daily and monthly income. At the same time, she also weaves shawls and other women's traditional wrap-around garments for sale. She has also purchased lots of household items for the house and her husband has also purchased more cable wire for expanding his satellite television business. He wants to expand to the interior of the village and also in the neighbouring villages. Helam said this is very reliable and very profitable, because they are the only one providing the satellite television network in the area. At the same time, with the loan from Kiva, she wants to buy more sewing machines, tailoring materials, cloth fabric, and other essential items for expanding her tailoring business.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics and sewing machines for expanding her tailoring business

loans.name: Felismina

texts.pt:
Felismina de 33 anos de idade, é solteira e tem 1 filho ainda sem idade escolar. Ela é negociante e trabalha numa banca em sua casa. 
O empréstimo será aplicado na compra de carne, frangos, refrescos, cervejas e arroz para reforçar o seu negócio.
O seu sonho é de crescer no seu negócio e também de voltar aos estudos para concluir o ensino médio. O seu maior desafio e de construir uma esplanada no quintal da sua casa para assim aumentar o seu rendimento.
texts.en:
Felismina is 33 years old, single and has 1 son who is still too young for school. She's a trader and works out of a stall in her own home.

This loan will be used to buy meat, chicken, sodas, beers and rice to sure up her business.

Her dream is to grow her business and also to get back to her studies so she can finish high school. Her biggest challenge is to build an outdoor café in her garden to increase her income.

loans.use: buy meat, chicken, sodas, beers and rice to sure up her business.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed operates a grocery business to earn an income. In his late thirties, Mohamed is married and has two children, ages two and seven, both of whom are enrolled in school. The family lives in Tombo. 

Mohamed established his grocery store in 2005 within the Tombo community. He wanted to create a permanent source of income to support his family.  He works at the business seven days per week from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. and says that the main challenge to his business is the price inflation of his goods.

Mohamed is requesting a loan in order to purchase such items as milk, pure water, cigarettes, and soft drinks to offer for sale. He hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow him to become more successful and continue to pay his children's school fees. 

In the future, Mohamed plans to expand his enterprise to wholesale. 

He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase such items as milk, pure water, cigarettes, and soft drinks to offer for sale

loans.name: Lucretia

texts.en:
Lucretia, age 40, sells eggs at the local market to earn an income. She lives in the West Point area, which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She and her husband have six children: the youngest is a two-month-old baby and the eldest is 21 years old. Two are presently enrolled in school and four live at home. Lucretia herself did not have the opportunity go to school.

Lucretia describes herself as a hard-working woman. She started this business two years ago with money given to her by mother. She sells eggs six days a week from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. and uses a shared taxi to bring her goods to her table. She likes her business because she enjoys interacting with her customers.

Lucretia is requesting a loan in order to purchase more eggs for her business. On the future, she plans to build a house for her children.  

She would like to offer her thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase eggs to offer for sale

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is 34 years old and lives in the West Point area which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is single and has eight children aged between 18 and 8. They are presently in school and all of them live at home. She stopped her education at the 11th grade. She described herself as a hardworking woman. 

For the past two years she has been selling eggs in the local market. She sells six days in a week from 7AM to 5PM; She likes her business because of the way customers buy from her, and she started this business with money given to her by her mother. She uses a shared taxi every time to get her goods to her business,. She is requesting a loan to purchase more eggs for her business. She plans to build a house for her children.  She would like to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase more eggs for her business

loans.name: Unith

texts.en:
Unith is a resident of Kifunjo - Rukungiri District and was born in 1980, thus being 33 years old. She is a married woman and a mother to two children who both go to school.

She attended other forms of education and became a teacher by profession. Thereafter, she started a small retail business of beans, flour, groundnuts and tomatoes in Rukungiri central market as her main business. She also has additional income from milk from her cattle farm. 

Unith however was facing financial problems that were affecting her business hence she approached UGAFODE Microfinance Limited (MDI) for assistance so as to achieve her dream of establishing a big and sustainable business.

She has been a loyal client of UGAFODE Microfinance Limited (MDI) and she is thankful for their helping hand towards her struggle to meet an improved standard of living. She needs the loan to overcome her biggest challenge of competition through increasing her stock.

loans.use: To buy fresh groceries for sale

loans.name: Dorris

texts.en:
Dorris is 34 years old and lives in the West Point area, which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is single, and she was unable to go to school. She describes herself as a hardworking woman.

For the past six years she has been selling oil, onions, eggs, and other foods, from a table in the local market. She sells six days in a week, from 8AM to 6PM. She enjoys her business, because of the flow of her customers. She started this business with money given to her by mother. She uses a shared taxi most of the time, to get her goods to her sales table.

Dorris is requesting a loan to purchase oil, onions, eggs, and other foods to resell at her table. Her plan is to build a house for her children.  She would like to say, "thanks," to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase oil, onions, eggs, and other foods to resell at her table

loans.name: Idrissa

texts.en:
Idrissa, age 43, sells slippers, sandals, and shoes at a busy market to earn a living. He has been engaged in this business for 16 years. He lives and works in the Waterloo area. He and his wife have three children between the ages of 10 and 26 years old. All three attend school. He also supports two additional dependents at home.

Idrissa tells us that the main challenge to his business is having insufficient capital to expand his business.

He has requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone in order to purchase slippers, sandals, and shoes to offer for sale. He says that the extra income from this loan will help him to increase his business and ensure the continued education of his children.

In the future, he would like to build his own shop. He is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase slippers, sandals, and shoes to offer for sale

loans.name: Memunatu

texts.en:
A married mother, Memunatu is 40 years old with four children, ages 13 years to 23 years. She runs a clothing enterprise in Jui Eastern area in Freetown. Her children are going to school. She began this business because she wants to generate her own income to support the home. 

She's been in this business for 10 years and sells shirts, blouses, jeans, and cosmetics.   She says that despite the challenges, she is a very hardworking woman and desires to educate her children.

Memunatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase a variety of shirts, blouses, jeans, and cosmetics.  She says that the extra resulting income will help her to increase her business and educate her children. In the future, she would like to expand to a wholesale store. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of shirts, blouses, jeans, and cosmetics

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 32-year-old Kadiatu from Waterloo Eastern area in Freetown. She is married with three children between the ages of 7 years and 13 years. Two of her children are attending school. She started business because she dropped out of school at an early age and decided to run a business because she didn’t want to be idle.  

Kadiatu runs a provisions shop; she sells  milk, sugar, Ovaltine, mayonnaise and drinks, etc.  She has been running this business since 2003. She works at the business seven days a week, twelve hours per day.  Kadiatu says that the main challenge to her business is that transporting her goods from the city to her business place is very difficult.

Kadiatu has requested a loan in order to purchase food items including milk, sugar, Ovaltine, mayonnaise and drinks for resale. The extra income from this loan will allow her to buy a plot of land and renovate her house. In the future, she plans to open a big provisions shop. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase food items including milk, sugar, Ovaltine, mayonnaise and drinks for resale

loans.name: Tonia

texts.en:
Tonia lives and works in St. Paul. St. Paul is home to the oldest market in Liberia and is known for its fish, due to its location by the sea. St. Paul is a suburb located just outside Monrovia, past the Free-port. It is one of the poorer areas and you will often find its residents living in sub-standard housing.

Tonia is 40 years old, married with five children, whose ages range from 27 to 11. Only the 11 year-old is in school and lives at home. For the past four years, Tonia has been operating a table at the market where she sells rice, soap, tissue, oil etc. She says that sometimes business goes slowly. Tonia says she started this business by selling around in the communities with the little goods she could afford--she learned this way of selling from her friends. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice, soap, tissue, oil, etc. for her business. Her plans is to expand her business even more.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, soap, tissue, oil, etc. for her business

loans.name: Eveline

texts.en:
This loan will help Eveline to establish a credit history and working capital for her business.
 
“I have always been a dancer. It is a passion and it is who I am at my core,” says Eveline. As the owner of The Cape Cod Dance Center, she values the positive impact her studio has on the young people in the local community. Having trained intensively in classical ballet herself while growing up in Canada, she has been exposed to the demanding art form all her life. She doesn’t always agree with the cut-throat approach to ballet instruction that so many young people are subjected to. “I believe I have succeeded in creating a space where each one feels safe and feels like they can truly be themselves,” states Eveline. She has provided a platform for so many young people to learn how to work hard and set goals for themselves – a key component to youth development. 

As a recent divorcee, Eveline is more financially vulnerable than ever. She has relied on personal credit for the past few years, which has negatively affected her credit. With this loan, Eveline will be able to separate her business expenses from her personal expenses, allowing her to rebuild a foundation for herself and for her business.

loans.use: to help establish credit history and working capital for her business

loans.name: Sabah

texts.en:
Sabah is 23 years old and lives in the West Point area, which has the most populated market in Montserrado County. She is unmarried, and she has four children between 7 years and 2 months old. They all live at home, and two of them are attending school. Sabah, herself, was unable to go to school.

She describes herself as a hardworking woman. For the past six years she has been selling eggs, from a table in the local market. She sells six days in a week, from 8AM to 6PM. She enjoys her business because of the flow of her customers. Sabah started this business with money given to her by her mother. Most of the time, she uses a shared taxi to get her eggs to her table.

Sabah is requesting a loan, which she will use to purchase eggs to resell at her table. Her plan is to build a house for her children. She would like to say "thanks," to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase eggs to resell, at her table in the market

loans.name: Carlos Alexander

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Tosagua cada quince días se reúne el Banco Comunal Amistad, este lugar se lo conoce por ser muy dinámico donde la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y a la cría de animales, por ser una zona con gran vegetación.

En este lugar vive el señor Carlos, tiene 21 años de edad, está soltero y vive en casa de los padres. Este es su tercer ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que le dan para poder forjarse un mejor porvenir.

Don Carlos trabaja en un taller que tiene su padre desde hace mas de 20 años en el cual él aprendió la profesión la misma que le permite salir adelante con el fruto de su trabajo, allí ellos arreglan bombas de agua y todo tipo de maquinas agrícolas, el trabajo es muy arduo ya que son muchos los clientes que llegan  a diario a pedirles que les realicen sus trabajos, ellos allí también venden repuestos y lubricantes que emplean en los arreglos de dichas maquinas por lo cual ofrecen un trabajo completo, el también realizan trabajos a domicilio, lo cual le permite ganar mucho mas.

Este crédito lo va utilizar en comprar lubricantes y varios repuestos que ellos emplean en su trabajo.
 
Su sueño es tener un taller propio.
texts.en:
The Amistad communal bank meets every two weeks s in the city of Tosagua. This place is known for being very dynamic, where a majority of the inhabitants work in agriculture or by raising animals. It is an area with a lot of vegetation.

Carlos lives in this area. He is 21 years old. He is single and he lives in his parents’ house. This is his third cycle with the communal bank. He likes the bank because with the support,  he can create a better future. 

Carlos works in a repair shop that his father has had for more than 20 years. He learned the profession which allows him to move forward with the results of his work. They repair water pumps and agricultural equipment. The work is very hard since  many customers come daily to request assistance now. They also sell parts and lubricants that are used by the equipment in order to run well. They also do services at homes which allow them to earn a lot more. 

This loan will be used to purchase lubricants and various parts that they use in their work. 

His dream is to have his own repair shop.

loans.use: purchase lubricants and parts.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 41 years old with six children, ages 3 years to 21 years. She runs a clothing enterprise in Waterloo Eastern area in Freetown. Her children are going to school. She began this business because she was a housewife and she wanted to stop sitting at home; instead she wanted to earn her own income. 

She's been in this business for 20 years and sells jeans, T-shirts and underwear.  She says that despite the challenges, she is a very hardworking woman and desires to educate her children.

Fatmata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase jeans, T-shirts and underwear. She says that the extra resulting income will help her to increase her business and improve their standard of living. In the future, she would like to build her own shop and expand her business more than even. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase jeans, T-shirts and underwear

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Meet 45-year-old Fatmata from Waterloo eastern area in Sierra Leone. She is married with 4 children who are between the ages of 12 and 27. Three of her children are currently attending school. In 1998, Fatmata established general store business within the community. She began her business because she was growing up keen to do business since she was a child.  She works at the business from 8:00am until 7:00 pm, 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is transportation.

Fatmata requires a loan in order to purchase more milk, mayonnaise, toothpaste, batteries, butter, and sardines. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to become more successful and pay her children's school fees. In the future, Fatmata plans to expand her enterprise to wholesale. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more milk, mayonnaise, toothpaste, batteries, butter, and sardines.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fathima, a married mother of 3, is in her late thirties. Here children are between 8 and 13 years old. She runs a clothing enterprise in Waterloo Eastern area in Freetown. Her children are going to school. She began this business because she did not go to school and she thought that business would be more profitable. 

She's been in this business for 15 years and sells wax cotton, lace, and women's clothing. She says that despite the challenges, she is a very hardworking woman and desires to educate her children.

Fatmata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase variety of clothing with traditional design patterns. She says that the extra resulting income will help her to increase her business and educate her children. In the future, she would like to open a supermarket. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of clothing with traditional design patterns.

loans.name: Amor Y Esperanza 2 Group

texts.en:
Raynold is one of the members of the group called Amor y Esperanza (Love and Hope) 2. This group is located in the rural area surrounding La Romana, where the sugarcane harvest and tourist industry dominate the economy. He makes his home in a simple structure with his three children and his long-term partner. He says that his most important challenge is to work hard by selling more products to provide for his family.



Raynold is excited to be taking his seventh loan with Esperanza, having repaid his previous loans and grown his business. He plans to use this loan to invest in his business by buying shoes, clothes and cosmetics such as body lotion, perfume, deodorant and other products. He will reinvest the profits in his business and take home money for food, clothes and other needs. His future plans are to develop a successful business within his local area. He thanks you all for your support!!!

loans.use: To buy shoes, cosmetics, clothes, and other products.

loans.name: Agusta

texts.en:
Agusta is taking a loan of $1,000 to improve her business. She runs a shop that helps her generate income for her family. 

She will use the loan to buy stock to keep in her store, such as clothing, shoes and slippers. She opened her shop two years ago with her own working capital of $1,600.  She is a hard-working woman, and she hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy clothing, shoes and slippers for resale.

loans.name: Dios Es Mi Pastor 5 Group

texts.en:
Maria is one of the members of the group Dios Es Mi Pastor 5 (God is My Shepherd), located in the city of San Pedro de Macoris. Maria sells clothing in her business. This is the 8th loan she has requested from Esperanza and she is planning to expand her business inventory by buying more clothes and others miscellaneous products. She is very excited to be part of this group, because she knows there are a lot of hardworking women whose lives are being changed by these loans, and she wants this to happen to her too.

With this new investment, Maria will be able to produce more and increase her sales. She started her business about 9 years ago with a small amount of money she had saved. She tells us that her challenges are to have her house, to learn how to write and read, and to help her children with their homework. She is also working to provides them with all she didn't get when she was a kid. Maria has 3 children and she lives together with them and their father, her long term partner. She is planning to reinvest her profits in the business to make it bigger and sustainable. Her dream is to see all her children become professionals and good people.

loans.use: To buy new clothes to sell

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en:
Meet Mariatu. She is a 44 year-old from Waterloo eastern area in Sierra Leone. She is divorced with 3 children between the ages of 7 and 11. Her children are currently attending school. 

In 2005, Mariatu established a local food business within the Waterloo community. She began her business because she wanted to create a permanent source of income to support her children; She works at the business from 8:00am until 7:00 pm, 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation of goods.

Mariatu requires a loan in order to purchase more local food like palm oil, gari, and ginger. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to become more successful and pay her children's school fees. In the future, Mariatu plans to expand her enterprise to wholesale. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more local food like palm oil, gari, and ginger.

loans.name: Calvin

texts.en:
Calvin was born and raised in the city of Los Angeles. He started working at the age of 14 with the Los Angeles Times newspaper company as a paperboy. Calvin said, “My childhood life consisted of school, sports and working my paper route for the Los Angeles Times, which is a local newspaper in the greater Los Angeles area.” As a child, Calvin always dreamed of owning his own newspaper/magazine.  

As an adult, he saw the lack of resources within the African-American community in Los Angeles, and so he launched Publisher Group, LLC in 1998 to help meet those needs. He was able to secure three companies to advertise in his magazine (Hughes L. Space Corporation, Bendix Corporation and General Dynamics), and now has a circulation of 40,000 readers. 

“We pay more for editing and graphic design because we don’t have any in-house editors or designers,” Calvin explains. With a loan of $9,600 from Kiva and PACE, Calvin will be able to hire two part-time editors and two sales reps for his company. He will also upgrade the desktop computer he uses to produce the magazine and obtain up-to-date software.

Calvin plans to increase his circulation from 40,000 readers to 100,000, and hopes more Fortune 500 companies will use his Publisher Group, LLC as a recruitment tool to reach people of color.

Calvin is working with PACE and Kiva because banks in his area do not lend to small businesses.

loans.use: to hire two part-time editors and two sales reps; also upgrade the desktop computer he uses to produce the magazine and obtain up-to-date software.

loans.name: Rumalda

texts.en:
Rumalda is taking a loan of $1,000 to improve her business. She is running a kiosk that helps her to generate income for her family. 

She will use the loan to buy slippers, cigarettes, soft drinks (Coca-Cola, Sprite, Sagiko and Fanta) and biscuits. She opened her kiosk a year ago with her own working capital of $400. Rumalda is a hard-working woman, and she hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy, slippers, cigarettes, soft drinks (Coca-Cola, Sprite, Sagiko and Fanta) and biscuits for her kiosk.

loans.name: Romano

texts.en:
This is Romano, age 29, and a resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. He is married to Geralyn, a housewife, and they have four children. Romano, together with his wife, manages their own household while operating a business. He works hard to support his family and provide income for their everyday expenses.

Romano is a fish vendor. He buys different kinds of fish wholesale and sells them by the kilo. He buys fish at the local fish port early in the morning. There are many patrons who prefer his products since they are assured of their freshness and cleanliness. His store is located in a temporary fish market. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community.  He earns a minimum of 800 Philippine Pesos in sales every day.

To help him continue operations, he is requesting a Php15,000 loan. He will use the loan to buy more fish.

Romano dreams of expanding his business and hopes to have a good life. He meets up with his co-fellowship members to share stories of his work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the word of God. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more fish needed in his business.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
This is Virginia. Her previous loan was a big help as she was able to buy more grocery items and toiletries. This gave her a chance for a bigger income. The loan also helped in her everyday needs. She has been in this business for seven years now. She works hard to provide income for her everyday needs.

She would like to apply for another 40,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Virginia hopes that her business will continue to be successful and dreams of being secure in the future. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her general store.

loans.name: Filomena

texts.pt:
Filomena de 50 anos de idade, é casada e tem 7 filhos. Vive com 4 filhos com idade escolar e os outros 2 são independentes. Ela também sustenta o pai enviando-lhe dinheiro para Magunde, onde ele se encontra.
Ela e o esposo são negociantes há mais de 10 anos e têm uma banca no quintal da sua casa. O empréstimo será aplicado na compra de farinha, feijão, amendoim, arroz, óleo e trigo para vender na banca.
A Filomena tem como esperança evoluir no seu negócio e passar a vender a grosso (actualmente vende a retalho). O seu maior desafio e de construir um verdadeiro estabelecimento comercial em sua casa em vez de ter apenas uma banca.
texts.en:
Filomena is 50 years old, married and has 7 children. She lives with 4 of her children who are of school-going age and the other 2 are independent. She also supports her father by sending money to Magunde where he lives.

Filomena and her husband have been traders for more than 10 years and have a stall in their back yard. This loan will be used to buy flour, beans, peanuts, rice, oil and wheat to sell from their stall.

Filomena hopes to evolve her business and start selling wholesale (she currently sells retail). Her biggest challenge is to build a real commercial establishment at her home instead of just having a stall.

loans.use: buy flour, beans, peanuts, rice, oil and wheat to sell from her stall.

loans.name: Sebastiao

texts.pt:
Sebastião tem 27 anos de idade, é casado e tem 2 filhos que ainda não estão em idade escolar. Ele é professor e a esposa é técnica da direcção provincial de educação. Ambos têm o mesmo horário de trabalho das 07:00h as 15:30h. O Sebastião também sustenta a mãe que vive com eles.

O empréstimo será aplicado na compra de areia, cimento, varões e blocos para concluir a construção da sua casa.
O Sebastião tem como sonho crescer profissionalmente e academicamente e garantir boas condições à sua família. O seu principal desafio é concluir a sua casa para melhor confortar a sua família e dar acompanhamento aos estudos dos seus filhos.
texts.en:
Sebastião is 27 years old, married and has 2 children who are still too young for school. He's a teacher and his wife works in the education department in their province. Both have the same working hours, from 07:00h as 15:30h. Sebastião also supports his mother who lives with them.

This loan will be used to buy sand, cement, rods and blocks to finish building their house.

Sebastião dreams of growing both professionally and academically and of providing his family with good living conditions. His main challenge is to complete the building work on his home in order to improve his family's comfort and to support his children in their studies.

loans.use: buy sand, cement, rods and blocks to finish building his house.

loans.name: Benita

texts.en:
This is Benita. Her previous loan helped her a lot, not just in her general store business, but also in her family's everyday expenses. She has been in this business for ten years. She and her husband, who is a driver, work hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Benita hopes to have a good life, and dreams that her business will continue to grow. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To buy grocery items, toiletries, beverages, and other products to sell.

loans.name: Alexandrina

texts.en: Alexandrina is requesting a $600 loan to buy additional supplies for her restaurant, such as fish, beer, meat and vegetables. She started her restaurant in 2013 and has been earning a good income from it. Alexandrina is happy with the loan she is taking. She wants to open a big restaurant in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional supplies for her restaurant, such as fish, beer, meat and vegetables.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en: Gemma, a 42-year-old married mother of two, resides in Catadman, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental, Philippines where she has been operating a buy-and-sell business with dried fish for five years. She also has a store selling goods in her locality. Gemma has requested a loan of PHP 4,500.00 from GDMPC micro credit to purchase inventory and raw ingredients. In the future, she wants to build a big house and expand her enterprise.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and raw ingredients for her retail store and dried fish business.

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
This is Nida. She previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan that she used to buy gardening materials and supplies needed in her flower business. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy gardening materials like wire, baskets, and supplies such as seed and fertilizer needed for her business. Her profits from this business will definitely help her sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Nida hopes that her business will continue to grow, and dreams of having a good future for her family. She meets with her co-fellowship members* every week, to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the group and from the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To buy gardening materials like wire, baskets, and supplies such as seed and fertilizer for her business.

loans.name: Campo Moro Group

texts.en: Maria is one of the members from Campo Moro Group. She is taking out a loan to add to her working capital to buy additional supplies for her store, such as slippers, cigarettes, soft drinks (Coca-Cola, Sprite, Sagiko and Fanta) and biscuits. She is a hard-working woman who started her business three years ago with her own working capital of $25.

loans.use: to buy, slippers, cigarettes, soft drinks (Coca-Cola, Sprite, Sagiko and Fanta) and biscuits

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en: Elisa is taking out a loan of $600 to improve her business. She is running a kiosk that helps her to generate income for her family. She will use the loan to buy stock for her store such as slippers, cigarettes, soft drinks (Coca-Cola, Sprite, Sagiko and Fanta) and biscuits. She opened her kiosk in 2004 with her own working capital of $20. Elisa is a hard-working woman and hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy, slippers, cigarettes, soft drinks (Coca-Cola, Sprite, Sagiko and Fanta) and biscuits.

loans.name: Mayra Azucena

texts.es:
Mayra, de 47 años de edad, es una humilde comerciante  habitante de la ciudad de León, ella  se dedica a vender ropa y mercadería en general, es madre soltera  tiene dos hijos de 30 y 18 años de edad, de los cuales solo uno está a cargo de ella. 
Su negocio lo inicio hace 4 años cuando viajaba a Honduras a comprar ropa para vender en León y sus comunidades poco a poco fue recogiendo capital para invertir en compras de nueva mercadería variada. Actualmente vende  ropa y cosméticos al contado y al crédito sus hijos la apoyan vendiendo junto con ella. 
Hoy esta necesitando el financiamiento para comprar ropa y perfumes para vender. Su principal deseo es que su familia tenga una mejor calidad de vida y que su hija puede estudiar. Dentro de sus planes futuros es tener una tienda de ropa usada y mercadería variada.
texts.en:
Mayra, who is 47 years old, is a humble businesswoman living in the city of León. She is dedicated to selling clothes and general goods. She is a single mother, and she has two children, who are 30 and 18 years old and of whom only one is in her care.

She started her business four years ago, when she traveled to Honduras to buy clothes to sell in León and its community. Little by little she was collecting capital to invest in the purchase of different types of new merchandise. Currently, she sells clothes and cosmetics for cash and by credit. Her children support her by working with her. 

Today, she needs a loan to buy clothes and perfumes to sell. Her main goal is that her family has a better quality of life and that her daughter can study. Among her future plans is to have a store to sell used clothing and other merchandise.

loans.use: to buy clothes and perfume to sell

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
Virginia continúa viviendo en la ciudad de Huancarani de la provincia de Paucartambo y donde realiza todo tipo de actividad, ella continua con la elaboración  de artesanía como por ejemplo chompas y frazadas pero también ahora está ayudando a su esposo en la elaboración de muebles de madera con el acabado de los muebles. 

En esta oportunidad Virginia requiere el préstamo para comprar más materiales como por ejemplo madera. Ya son varios años que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien gracias a su empeño que pone en su trabajo. 

Virginia continúa en el banco comunal “Mamacha Rosario” de la Asociación Arariwa y se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma. (La socia aparece en la fotografia junto con su esposo).
texts.en:
Virginia continues living in the city of Huancarani in the province of Paucartambo, and this is where she does all types of activities. She continues with making crafts, such as sweaters and blankets, but she also now is helping her husband make wood furniture by doing finishing on the furniture.

At this time, Virginia requires a loan to buy more materials, such as wood. It has already been many years that she has worked in this business, and it has been going very well thanks to the determination she puts into her work.

Virginia continues with the community bank “Mamacha Rosario” of the microfinance organization Asociación Arariwa, and she is thankful for the opportunity offered through this group. As a result, she promises to comply with repaying the loan according to the schedule. Virginia appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: to buy more materials, such as wood

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.es:
Felicitas continua viviendo en la ciudad de Huancarani de la provincia de Paucartambo y donde realiza todo tipo de actividad, ella continua con la venta de comestibles pues tiene una pequeña tienda de abarrotes en su domicilio. Ya son varios años que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien gracias a su empeño que pone en su trabajo. Ella también ahora se está dedicando a la crianza de animales menores como cuyes y chanchos.  

En esta oportunidad Felicitas requiere el préstamo para comprar más mercadería como por ejemplo aceite, fideos, golosinas, sacos de azúcar, sacos de fideos, sacos de arroz y otras cosas más.

Felicitas continua en el banco comunal “Mamacha Rosario” de la Asociación Arariwa y se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Felicitas continues living in the city of Huancarani in the province of Paucartambo, where she performs all types of work. She continues to sell groceries from her small grocery store located in her home. It has already been many years that she has worked in this business, and it has been going very well thanks to the determination she puts into her work. She is also now dedicated to raising young animals, such as guinea pigs and pigs.

At this time, Felicitas requires a loan to buy more merchandise, such as oil, noodles, sweets, bags of sugar, bags of noodles, bags of rice, and other things.

Felicitas continues in the community bank “Mamacha Rosario” in the microfinance organization Asociación Arariwa, and she is thankful for the opportunity offered through this group. As a result, she promises to make repayments according to the repayment schedule.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise such as bags of sugar, bags of noodles, bags of rice, and other items.

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita is a 52-year-old widow with three children who lives in Tangub City. She earns a living by selling food and home use products. 
She has been in business for years. She also opened another line of business offering foods in her eatery. Juanita has applied for a loan of PHP 3,700.00 from GDMPC  micro credit to purchase goods and utensils to be used for her eatery
She has been a member of GDMPC since 2009.  She hopes to improve the general living conditions of the entire family.

loans.use: to purchase goods and utensils to be used for her eatery

loans.name: Jelyn

texts.en:
This is Jelyn, 26, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. Her husband is Damian, a tricycle driver, and she is a mother to her six children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Jelyn operates a Barbeque stall. She regularly buys pork, meat and chicken entrails that she prepares and cooks and sells in the afternoon in her barbeque stand near her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like meat, pork and chicken. 

Jelyn hopes that her business will continue to grow and dreams that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

 * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more meat, pork and chicken needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy additional stock of plastic wares and hardware to sell.

loans.name: Alfreda

texts.en: Alfreda is 40 years old and lives in Kinuman Sur, Ozamis City. She is able to provide for the needs of her four children with the 2,200 PHP she earns monthly from her vegetable production business. Her business supplements the income her husband earns from farming. Alfreda is applying for a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer, such as manure. She wants to expand her garden and able to improve the family's house.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, such as manure

loans.name: Meldat

texts.en:
Meldat is a 32-year-old man married to Sarci, a 32-year-old woman; they have two children, Sartika, 8, an elementary student and  Jessica, 2. 

Meldat has been selling fish since 2004, with a starting capital of IDR 500.000. His daily income is between IDR 40.000 – 80.000/day. 

Due to seasonal variations, the price for him to purchase fish has increased, and in turn, he is asking for a loan from TLM of IDR 3,000,000. The loan will be used to buy fish, and to save for his children’s education fees. 

He hopes his business will run well so he will be able to repay the loan and put his children through school.

loans.use: to buy fish and to save for his children’s education fees.

loans.name: Rosary

texts.en: Rosary is 33 years old and married with three dependents. She lives in Carmen Annex, Osamiz City. Rosary owns and operates a motorcycle transport service business. She established the business as a way to generate extra income and now makes PHP 8,000 per month. She has engaged in this type of service for six years. Recently, she requested a loan of PHP 24,500 from GDMPC. She intends to use the loan to purchase a new set of tires and pay for maintenance. In the future, Rosary wants to expand her business and to have another motorcycle.

loans.use: to purchase new set of tires and pay for maintenance

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is applying for a loan of $ 800 (USD) to improve her business. She is running a business in front of her house selling palm wine, noodles and gasoline. She is making a good income from selling palm wine, noodles and gasoline and she wants to buy more stock with the loan. She is living in a town near the main road so she sells every day and many people come to buy. She started her business in 2013 with her own working capital $300.

loans.use: to buy and sell palm wine, noodles and gasoline

loans.name: Casilda

texts.es: Casilda, de 56 años es una mujer alegre, vive en compañía de su esposo Antonio y sus 4 hijos a los que cuida en la casa que adquirieron hace muchos años. Casilda se dedica a la ganadería y agricultura. Desde ese entonces comenzó a criar vacas y camélidos. En la actualidad posee vacas, ovejas y llamas. Los cuales cuida con mucho esmero y dedicación, “paso la mayor parte del tiempo en pastar a mis animales en las alturas, donde comen pastos naturales, por esa razón son de buena calidad. Me instalo ahí por muchas semanas, llevo todo lo necesario para alimentarme”, afirma. Todos los días realiza queso, gracias a la leche que producen los animales. Comenta que la otra actividad económica que desarrolla es la agricultura pero en menor cantidad, pues en la crianza de animales es donde obtiene mayores ganancias, sobre todo en la venta de queso de buena calidad. Este es su cuarto crédito con KIVA y se siente agradecida por el apoyo financiero recibido, razón por la cual se compromete a ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas. Casilda, invertirá los S/.1500 soles en la compra de 2 vacas de raza.
texts.en:
Casilda, 56 years old, is a very happy woman who lives with her husband, Antonio, and their four children. They live in a house the family bought many years ago. Casilda makes a living raising livestock and farming. She is currently raising cows, sheep, and llamas. Casilda, with much dedication, takes very good, watchful care of her animals. She says, "I spend most of my time in the pasture with my animals in the highlands where they can graze on natural pasture. That's why they are good quality animals. I spend weeks at a time up there and bring what I need to eat." 

Each day, Casilda also makes cheese, thanks to the milk that the animals produce. She comments that she also grows some crops, but in small quantities. Raising animals is the activity that provides most of her income, especially selling quality cheeses. 

This is Casilda's fourth Kiva loan. She feels very grateful for the financial support she has received, so she pledges to be punctual with her repayments. Casilda will invest the 1500 Peruvian soles in the purchase of two cows of a good breed.

loans.use: to buy two cows of a good breed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages to add to her inventory.

loans.name: Rufino

texts.en:
Rufino is a 46-year-old man who has three children. They live in the village of Sinusa, city of Ozamiz, Misamis Occidental. He's a farmer who plants, grows and harvests corn on a plot of land located in the village where he lives. He chose this line of work because it was his father's legacy and also because it produces food for his family. Corn is the staple food in his community and also earns him a profit, since he sells part of his produce in the local market.
He's requesting a loan so he can purchase fertilizer in order to adequately maintain his corn crop.
He dreams of using his profits to improve his home so that he can provide better living conditions for his family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Novelyn

texts.en:
This is Novelyn. She previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts and accessories and for the maintenance of her motorized tricycle unit. Her earnings were a big help in meeting the family's personal, household and business expenses. 

She would like to apply for another 40,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of her tricycle unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Novelyn dreams to have more tricycles and dreams that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts and maintenance of her motorized tricycle unit.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for beauty products and hair products needed in her salon.

loans.name: Bienvenida

texts.en:
This is Bienvenida. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy the tools that she needs in her repair shop. The loan also helped in their everyday expenses. Aside from the repair shop, she also has a loading station and does direct selling.

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan to buy other tools for the repair shop and for the salary of the workers. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Bienvenida hopes that her businesses will continue to grow. She meets every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for other tools in the repair shop and for the salary of the workers.

loans.name: Rica

texts.en:
This is Rica's fifth loan cycle. Her last loan, just like her previous loans, was a big help in her business. She was able to generate more income. The loan also helped in their everyday needs. She and her husband are working hard to provide for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for a new 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan for her to purchase raw ingredients like sugar, bananas and other products needed in her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Rica dreams that her family will be lifted out from poverty. She meets up with her co-fellowship members weekly to share stories of her life and business, where she can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw ingredients like sugar, bananas and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Dios Ante Todo 1, 2 & 3 Group

texts.en:
Margo is the coordinator of her group, Dios Ante Todo 1, 2 and 3 (God First), located in a village where most of the citizens are Haitians. She lives in a modest home with one of her three children. With this effort, she can make extra income and help her long-term partner. In the meantime, she enjoys doing business and taking care of her children. 

Margo is excited to be taking her sixth loan with Esperanza. She runs a clothing sales business. She has had her business for nearly three years. She began her business by selling a dozen pairs of jeans she bought with her first loan.

Margo is planning to use this loan to invest in her business by buying clothing in different sizes for men and women. She will reinvest the profits in her business by purchasing more products and expanding her business with more options and new clients. She dreams of becoming someone with a very important business.

Margo represents her group and many Haitians who immigrated to the Dominican Republic to improve their lives. In this group is a sample of 15 Haitian families fighting to overcome the Haiti crisis. Thanks to you for supporting this group.

loans.use: to buy clothing in different sizes for men and women.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy is a 43-year-old resident of Catadman, Ozamis City. She provides for her children's needs from the little amount -- 5,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) she gains monthly from her own sari-sari (or variety) store, and the income her husband gets by driving.
